text: Before the debates begin, I would like to give the floor to Caroline Roose before today's first vote. Caroline Roose requested to speak on the EU-Seychelles Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement and its implementation (Protocol 2020-2026) pursuant to Article 159(4) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Caroline Roose
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, last night the European Parliament gave its consent to the sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Seychelles. The agreement sets out the rules governing the access of EU fishing vessels to Seychelles waters in exchange for fishing rights for European tuna vessels. The European Union provides Seychelles with financial support of 5.3 million euros per year and technical support. From a financial point of view, the agreement between the European Union and Seychelles represents the fifth largest eu-largest fishing agreement in force and the largest in the Indian Ocean. This agreement follows on from a previous agreement signed in 2007 and a previous protocol signed in 2013. The new agreement presents many positive advances: it should improve fisheries control, the fight against IND fishing, it will strengthen scientific cooperation and data collection. In terms of transparency, we are particularly pleased with the Seychelles government's commitment to publish the fisheries agreements it signs with other states. One of the specific features of this report is that the fishing sector in Seychelles, including small-scale fishing, also fishes for tuna. In fact, European vessels are in direct competition with local fishermen. It is crucial that the fishing sector is better listened to and included in the negotiations. Local fishermen, scientists and NGOs have warned that fishing efforts are too large in the region and that albacore tuna is in critical condition. We deplore the fact that more vessels will be allowed to fish under the protocol. We also call on the European Commission to be more vigilant in the use of sectoral support. Indeed, local fishermen and French journalists have shown that some of the money supposedly used for local fishing has been used to finance a multi-million euro wharf that is used only for European industrial fishing. Small-scale fishing cannot access it. We reiterate these points in the report and I invite my colleagues to support it widely. This report will be voted on today.

text: The first item is the debate on the oral question on democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law (O-000065/2020 - B9-0023/20) - (RSP 2020/2790) on the impact of the measures introduced on Covid19 by Juan Fernando López Aguilar on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. I would like to inform Members that none of the debates in this meeting will be heard on the basis of an application and that we will not accept blue cards and points of order.  In addition, speeches can be expected from Parliament's contact offices in the Member States via a remote link.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner Reynders, you know that yesterday I had the opportunity to recall that this institution — this European Parliament — is the only directly elective of the Union: it represents citizens and therefore also expresses its concerns and fears in the face of what is turning out to be the worst crisis in the history of the Union.  Unexpectedly, when citizens responded to the electoral call with an increase in participation at last, they were unaware that we were aaboding in a crisis that has impacted all our vital signs.  But the European Parliament, representing citizenship, has responded from minute one. We adopted a resolution in April, another in May and another in June, on the impact that the emergency measures taken by the Member States in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic and their havoc were having on which, in my view, it is the most precious asset of the European experience: the unrestricted free movement of persons at the internal borders of the Union. And, in line with this concern, we raise an oral question, which is equivalent to what is considered an appeal in parliamentary law in many Member States, followed by a resolution.  And here is the Resolution: twenty-three recitals and twenty-three other paragraphs in which we demand that the Member States and the Commission live up to it, with a clear message: the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights matter; law matters, law matters.  Not only does it always matter, but it particularly matters in times of crisis, because a crisis challenges us about what we claim to be; you can get the best out of us, but also the worst. And it is very important that, by now, when the whole year 2020 has been consumed by the reaction to the pandemic, let us start to deduce some lessons, let us draw some conclusions.  And the first, indeed, is that the law is here to be taken seriously, and this conveys a message that has to do with the principles of necessity and proportionality but, above all, of time frame, temporary limitation when taking measures that can have an impact on the rule of law, democracy, the quality of democracy that we stilate in the European Union , its Member States and which is a principle constituting , Article 2 — of the European experience, and the fundamental rights of citizens.  And this Resolution fully reviews the impact these emergency measures have had on the fundamental rights of citizens, first of all, on those enshrined in the Charter.  For starters, the free movement of people. There is a Schengen Borders Code; there is a Directive on free movement, which has been ignored, if not constilled, in a hurry to take emergency measures. And the Commission is responsible, as guardian of the Treaties, for ensuring that Member States follow the principles of proportionality and necessity in restrictions on free movement and for their temporary limitation, so that, as soon as possible, those restrictions are lifted.  Similarly, we deal with the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter: freedom of expression — even an expression of dissent in the face of some of the measures taken by the Member States — protest, right of assembly, the right of assembly. Undoubtedly, rights conditioned by emergency measures, conditioned by the need to ensure public health, but have neither been extinguished nor disappeared from the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Therefore, measures impacting these rights must also be proportionate and time-limited.  We are particularly concerned with the free communication of ideas, because if we deal in this European Parliament with misinformation, we must deal even more when this toxic misinformation harms people's health; misinformation aimed at confusing or questioning scientific knowledge and generating a state of fear and anxiety easily exploitable by demagogues and populists, who fish in the river scrambled with the fear of citizens in the face of the impact of the pandemic.  It is therefore very important that the European Union adopts the necessary strategies to defend itself against cyberattacks, against cybercrime, but also against misinformation.  We are particularly concerned about the impact of emergency measures on criminal law and prison law: disproportionate, repressive criminal measures, disproportionate sanctions, lacking seats in the principles of sanctioning law; and we are also concerned about the impact on democracy and parliamentary control and control Judicial.  These are the recommendations of the Venice Commission, are the recommendations of the European Court of Human Rights and the Court of Justice, which cannot be violated or ignored, even in times of pandemic.  We therefore require Member States to draw lessons, that, where there have been emergency measures, these emergency measures be consistent with their constitutional systems, and that, where there is no prior provision, the specific legislation to enable us to respond is now adopted; and, to the Commission, to monitor and continuously monitor the attainment of Member States' responses to the rules of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights.

name: Didier Reynders
text: membre de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames, Messieurs, je voudrais tout d’abord vous remercier pour votre engagement concernant l’impact des mesures d’urgence, prises dans le contexte de la lutte contre la COVID-19, sur la démocratie, les droits fondamentaux et l’état de droit. Au-delà de son incidence sanitaire et économique, la crise qui nous frappe a engendré toute une série de défis pour nos sociétés, y compris, comme cela vient d’être rappelé, pour les valeurs fondamentales de l’Union. Tous les États membres ont pris des mesures exceptionnelles pour protéger la santé publique, mesures qui ont eu pour conséquence des restrictions de certains droits et libertés fondamentales.  La plupart des États membres ont déclaré une forme d’état d’urgence ou octroyé des pouvoirs spéciaux d’urgence. Cela a été fait, soit en vertu de dispositions constitutionnelles, soit en vertu de la législation sur la protection de la santé publique.  La modification ou la suspension de l’équilibre normal des pouvoirs au niveau national peut effectivement poser des problèmes particuliers pour l’état de droit. La crise s’est avérée être un test de résistance permettant d’évaluer la résilience des systèmes nationaux en temps de crise.  La Commission a insisté dès le départ sur le fait que les mesures prises en réaction à la crise doivent respecter nos valeurs fondamentales, telles qu’énoncées dans les traités. Les mesures d’urgence doivent notamment être limitées à ce qui est nécessaire, strictement proportionnées, clairement limitées dans le temps et conformes aux garanties constitutionnelles ainsi qu’aux normes européennes et internationales. En outre, les gouvernements doivent veiller à ce que les mesures fassent l’objet d’un contrôle parlementaire régulier, dans le plein respect des équilibres démocratiques. These key requirements were reflected following the Commission’s proposal in the country-specific recommendations adopted by the Council, in the context of the European Semester this year. The Commission has been proactively monitoring the emergency measures taken in all the Member States. The first Annual Report on the Rule of Law highlighted the need to maintain established checks and balances, including the role of parliaments in particular, when the measures taken affect fundamental rights. The resilience of the justice systems was also put to the test. A number of Member States have taken measures to reduce the impact of the pandemic and were able to restart hearings applying distancing rules or video—conferencing techniques.  The COVID-19 pandemic has shown the importance of accelerating reforms to digitalise the handling of cases by the judicial institutions, the exchange of information and documents with parties and lawyers, and continued and easy access to justice for all. We will continue to discuss with the Member States about a real investment in the digitalisation of the justice systems in all the Member States. On data protection, the Commission has already provided guidance and recommendations to Member States, in particular on apps supporting the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.  The European interoperability gateway for contact-tracing apps is now operational. It allows people to receive alerts and declare infections, also when abroad, using their home country’s app. It ensures a high level of personal data protection and security.  The Commission has continued to monitor the situation and tried to receive a positive answer from all the Member States to take part in such an interoperability gateway. It’s not already the case with all the Member States, but we are progressing. Néanmoins, ce sont les autorités nationales de contrôle de la protection des données et les cours et tribunaux nationaux qui sont en première ligne dans ce domaine, car ils ont la responsabilité principale de veiller au respect des règles. Ces autorités ont pour tâche de conseiller les législateurs nationaux et de surveiller que l’ensemble des opérateurs, publics ou privés, respectent la loi. Elles se coordonnent au sein du Comité européen de la protection des données et la Commission a régulièrement des échanges avec ce Comité européen de la protection des données. The crisis has also had an impact on democracy, electoral processes and freedom of expression. The COVID-19 pandemic has indeed been accompanied by an unprecedented flood of false or inaccurate information that can create confusion and distrust, undermine an effective public health response and have a negative impact on democratic institutions.  In June this year, the Commission adopted a communication as regards disinformation during the pandemic and getting the facts right. The upcoming democracy action plan will address further challenges along three main pillars: electoral integrity, a free and plural media and combating disinformation.  Closely linked to this action plan, in December the Commission will also issue its EU citizenship report which will present initiatives to promote the enjoyment by EU citizens of their civic rights under EU law. By the end of the year, the Commission will also publish a new strategy on implementation of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and we will come with the first annual report on the new strategy next year before Parliament.  With regard to the right to free movement, a right cherished by many EU citizens, the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination must always be respected when restrictions are being considered. Since March 2020, the Commission has adopted a number of guidelines and communications, and following a Commission proposal the Council adopted on 13 October a recommendation on a coordinated approach to the restrictions on free movement in response to the COVID-19 pandemic – you know the common map that we now have published by the ECDC (European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control) every week – and we try also to fight against all possible forms of discrimination also with a dialogue between the Commission and the Member States.  Just to give an example, in the past months we have seen since the end of August a possible discrimination in Hungary with controls at the border except for travellers coming from the other three Visegrad countries – from the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Poland. I have had many contacts with the Hungarian authorities and at the end of October they prolonged the measures about border control but without any exceptions now for the three Visegrad countries. So the dialogue between the Commission and the Member States is also very important to try to avoid some kind of discrimination.  Thanks again for this opportunity to explain what we have been doing since the beginning of the crisis, since March, in the different fields and, of course, we will continue to do that. Oversight by the judicial systems and oversight by the parliaments, and also by the European Parliament is very important in the crisis and I am looking forward to this debate and to hearing your views on this important matter.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, governments have put in place extraordinary measures to contain the pandemic. In general, these measures have led to restrictions on fundamental rights. The problem is not whether a confinement or a curfew is necessary ⸺eso belongs to scientists⸺ but whether such limitations on individual freedom are adopted in accordance with the guarantees of the rule of law. But I wonder today whether this parliament, closed and remote, is in a position to remind other open Parliaments of the importance of defending the democratic principle against quarantine.  Yes, I am concerned that, covered by health urgency, we ourselves are resigning from democratic urgency. I am concerned that hundreds of our colleagues cannot ask for the floor in this House because they do not live in the capital of their country and are not allowed to travel either; that we have elite Deputies, who can talk here, and Class Two MPs; that we do not have interpretation in all languages. I am concerned that our agendas are becoming more and more insufficient, our speaker shifts shorter and that we will vote on the financial framework, recovery plan or Brexit without amendments or real debate. I am concerned that all Parliaments, including Belgium's, are open, and the European Parliament, rather than being the most transparent and ensuring that its members can work safely, is the only one who chooses to close their doors and point out their Members as if they were to blame for contagion. If, when we need it most, we remain closed and remote, we are not fooled that soon the public wonders what the European Parliament is for.

name: Katarina Barley
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Corona pandemic is a disaster for many, an individual disaster, but it is a challenge for all of us, and it is also a challenge for democracy. It places great responsibility on those who have to decide on the measures that we must take to contain this pandemic.  All Member States have taken measures, most of which have declared a form of emergency. These measures are very different and we have produced a detailed report on these measures in the Rule of Law Monitoring Group chaired by Sophie in't Veld, who will also be speaking at the same time, which is really worth reading.  There are the usual suspects – Let me call them – who are taking advantage of the situation to restrict fundamental rights far unduly. We have seen in Hungary, for example, that there has been rather unwelcome access to Parliament's rights. And in Poland, attempts have been made to restrict the right to vote. But in almost all states, there is lively discussions – as here – about what is appropriate and what is not, in almost all states. And that is a good thing, because that is the essence of democracy. We can only intervene in fundamental rights as far as is absolutely necessary. All measures must be proportionate, they must be temporary, they must be clearly defined and they must be subject to parliamentary and judicial control. And then there is ... (incomprehensible heckling) Any parliamentarian can come here. (incomprehensible heckling) No one is forbidden to come here. I do not know what you want from me now, but no one is forbidden to come here.  And then, of course, we have to look at particularly vulnerable groups. We know that domestic violence against women and children has increased. We know that minorities have been further restricted, some have been made scapegoats.  So: times of crisis also for democracy. We must all ensure that fundamental rights are protected – here and at national level.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I would like to ask my fellow Members to give everyone the opportunity to comment.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – I would ask for a minimum respect for colleagues, please!  Madam President, I think most of us agree that measures have to be taken against the pandemic. There are very few people who deny that, and they are believing in conspiracies, but measures have to be necessary, proportionate and time—limited. We see huge differences across the Member States and that’s actually very strange because, even if the measures are national, fundamental rights are European and they should apply equally to all European citizens. And, as this crisis is lasting longer than just a few weeks, we have to be very vigilant and we have to be very critical because, as Ms Barley also indicated, there are some governments who are very cynically exploiting this pandemic to expand their own authoritarian empires. Yes, it’s the usual suspects, it’s Hungary and it’s Poland. Yes, it’s again at the expense of women’s rights and LGBTI people’s rights. On democracy and the functioning of Parliament – because democratic scrutiny is more important than ever when governments get exceptional powers or the executives get exceptional powers and we all realise that there are practical and legal restrictions on our work – I very much concur with what has just been said. Why is the European Parliament the only parliament in Europe and indeed the only parliament in Brussels which is virtually shut down? And it has been done by a unilateral decision of the President of this House, there has not been a political decision, it’s not time—limited ... (Applause) ... and I think we give completely the wrong signal to the citizen. We should be here, and indeed we are not banned from coming here, but we are banned from physically participating in meetings, we are banned from meeting face to face, at the coffee machine too, because that’s part of parliamentary work as well. So finally, I think we need more harmonisation, also in the exit strategy from this situation, because even if the countries are hit in different ways by the pandemic, all EU citizens are entitled to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the entire European Union. (Applause)

name: Sergey Lagodinsky
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Every time the COVID situation in Hungary becomes particularly fragile, Viktor Orban looks under the belt of his citizens. In May of this year, it was the Orban government that considered it urgently necessary to remove the recognition of transgender people from identity cards. Now, in the midst of the second wave, in the middle of the wave, it is a matter of ensining in the Constitution that only Christian gender images in the families are in order.  We know these tricks from the trick box of the totalitarians, from Russia and Turkey. It is always a question of distracting our own citizens from their own failures. If not bread, then at least the games – this skewer race at the expense of the minorities is: Judit Varga, Viktor Orban, L'szlé Tr snnyi. Ladies and gentlemen here in the European Parliament from the Fidesz party, do you have nothing better to do?  We have better things to do, ladies and gentlemen. For months, this Parliament has been negotiating reconstruction funds, including for Hungary. But this year, 2020 will decide not only the future of our economy, but also the future of our democracy. Because fair-weather democracy – everyone can do that. But at the end of a crisis in the midst of a democracy, continuing to work and live is the high art of freedom and enlightenment. We have been working on this weekly in the LIBE exclusion observer group since the outbreak of the crisis, and we have seen freedom of expression and freedom of the press restricted in many countries – Hungary, Italy, Romania – and an app in Poland that has seen people, almost all countries abolished the right to asylum, and how hostility towards Asian people or de-bordering of Roma settlements has been introduced, for example, in Bulgaria. With this resolution, we make it clear that times of crisis require crisis instruments. But we also say quite clearly: COVID times are not anything—goes—times. Fundamental rights remain, and we in the European Parliament are also ensuring that this is the case.

name: Hermann Tertsch
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, it is true that, in all countries, the expansion of the virus has forced restrictions on common life, especially mobility and certain behaviours, but it is also true that all governments have suddenly been legitimized by the pandemic and, above all, by the fear of the population, and are exercising a power that would be crossed out under normal conditions , in general, always abusive.  And many governments have taken the opportunity to impose absolutely unjustified levels of arbitrariness and police coercion and sanction. Some have gone further and used the pandemic to change the legal situation, take serious administrative action, without opposition or, worse, to crush critics and punish the protocol, calling everyone denier or conspiratorial.  If this is expected in dictatorships like Cuba and Venezuela, where it has in fact happened, it is scandalous in the democracies and countries of the European Union. And we are not talking about the usual suspects - as is said here from Hungary and Poland - but from Spain, where a social-communist government has imposed a six-month state of alarm that goes against the Constitution, as it is expressly limited in it to a fortnight, with mandatory parliamentary renewal.  Under the pretext of misinformation, many are trying to impose this censorship which, in Spain, has already become practically official, and Parliament has been shut down in practice, and the total arbitrariness of the Government of Sánchez and Iglesias is causing serious damage to the democratic quality of Spain. The European Union needs to pay particular attention to what is happening in Spain.

name: Malin Björk
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We have an ongoing public health crisis, but we also have an ongoing rule of law and democracy crisis of which many of us are very aware. Certain restrictions on rights and freedoms in order to protect life and health are, of course, necessary, but, as has been said here, not all the measures that have been put in place do not actually apply. These chronic states of emergency, I think, should be very, very careful. The issue of the limited role of parliaments, the freedom of the media, which has been restricted and freedom of expression that has been restricted, has also been raised, but we have also seen how fundamental human rights have been attacked in the context of the very special situation in which we live. Men's violence against women has increased. I must also highlight the situation of refugees. I've been on Lesbos since Moria burned. It puts people behind barbed wire to so-called "isolate" people. It's not dignified. It is a shame that the island camps have not been evacuated and that people have not been allocated to other EU countries. It's a disgrace. If we do not have a plan now, a plan to get out of this situation on the rule of law and democracy, then we will not succeed. And we are consolidating, we risk consolidating authoritarian regimes. So the Commission: you have to put a plan on the table, not refer to reports to come.

name: Κώστας Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, in Greece, the New Democracy Government — like all governments in every Member State of the European Union — is not only not taking substantial measures against the pandemic but, in the midst of a capitalist crisis, is escalating the attack with new sweeping reversals in labour rights in favour of business groups. The condition for them to be imposed is the further criminalisation and intensity of the repression of labour struggles, the restriction and the blow to the right to strike, protest and trade union action.  The resolution — despite the inexpensive concerns — justifies all this, as long as it is — as it says — necessary, proportionate, temporary and on a solid legal basis, and calls on the Member States to restrict the right to demonstration only — as it says — where it is absolutely necessary and justified. Meanings-"rubbers", that is. In the name of the pandemic, it also gives a green light for tracking applications and any personal data processing folder. The people, through their organized fight for their modern needs and respecting all protection measures, will defend their rights and in practice annul reactionary laws and decrees.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Wherever freedom, democracy and the rule of law are threatened in the world, we speak out, for example at the beginning of the Corona pandemic, when the majority of this House also criticised national parliaments and governments in Europe for their possibly excessive actions.  But what impact does Corona have on our work? All the national parliaments meet, and the Belgian Parliament even visited this Chamber a few weeks ago. And we? Some people think that we should stay at home! We all know that parliamentarianism is much more than the electronic reading of opinions or electronic participation in votes. The exchange of arguments, the heart of parliamentary democracy, does not really work. So that there is no misunderstanding, for the duration of the pandemic, the remote possibilities for many Members are better than nothing. But it is not right for freely elected Members to be banned from attending meetings and all that is part of our functioning parliamentary life. Even today, clear rules of procedure, such as Rule 156, are being broken, and we obviously present cannot prove our presence. The free mandate is not the right of us MEPs. It is the right of the citizens that we represent. And never – especially in pandemic times – can we deprive people of their democratic rights and restrict the free mandate. This must be rectified as soon as possible, otherwise our House and democracy in Europe will continue to suffer.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Madam President! The Covida pandemic has left its influence on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in all Member States. The problem arises when influence in some countries turns into a persistent, hard-to-erase seal. I am sure that each of us has an opinion, including a lack of action on government action, but it is dangerous when dissent is used as an excuse for a more permanent change in the balance of power. The resolution makes it very clear that measures that dangerously undermine the country's fundamental systems, from restricting freedom of movement, expression and information, freedom of religion, the right to family life, education and work. All this, and more, has been made by the governments of the Union, by the governments of the Union, on the pretext of saving people's lives. Do you? How many lives have Hungary saved when Hungarian President Orban has been given the power to rule by decrees completely past parliament during a state of emergency? How many lives were saved when the Slovenian government of Janez Janše in the first wave restricted and disabled the operation of many NGOs? For example, how many lives will it save with new penalties for protesters of up to EUR 10,000 for gathering in public places, or a desire to give the army additional powers to protect the external border? Completely absurd decisions that have nothing to do with fighting the virus and saving lives. Therefore, a sincere call for Member States to work exclusively for the good of the people and to take measures that are necessary, proportionate and temporary. Consultation and cooperation with the medical profession, with civil society and political opposition is key. Only by working together will we succeed, the sooner we know it, the sooner we will overcome this crisis. I wish everyone a great deal of health and all good!

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew).
text: – Madam President, fighting the virus is not easy at all, in many European countries we see protests, dissatisfaction with restrictions, violent manifestations. People are tired.  In this context, Parliament's resolution is important because it covers a very wide spectrum of rights and includes guidelines explaining what the behaviour of a responsible State in the face of the pandemic should mean.  But the responsibility of governments means, in the difficult context we are experiencing, also courageous action to protect the right to life of citizens, and the measures taken must be legal, necessary and proportionate.  And in Romania there were problems, there were attempts at censorship, the government communicated insufficiently and limited the right to information. In many places in Europe we have seen freedom of the press threatened by arbitrary government interventions or funding that undermines the independence of journalists. But the right to education has also been seriously affected as a result of the closure of schools.  Truly responsible leaders are fighting today to maintain the right balance between the need for health security of society and real respect for human rights in times of crisis. European governments and institutions must communicate permanently, effectively, courageously and empathetically with people, and the transparency of actions and procurement is fundamental in this time of crisis.  Only together can we overcome this crisis, governments and people. And that can be done, with respect for the fundamental rights that are part of European DNA.

name: Sylwia Spurek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The time of the pandemic has exposed further weaknesses of the European Union: we lack mechanisms to protect human rights, a system that guarantees rights, creates mechanisms to deter governments from breaking them, which is ready to react quickly when violations occur. The European Union must create such a system.  The victims of COVID-19 are not only the sick and the dying, not only business, but also women experiencing domestic violence, because in the European Union there are countries where women do not feel safe in their own home. The victims of COVID-19 are women in Poland, to whom the so-called Court under the cover of a pandemic once again takes away the rights to legal and safe abortion. All this is happening in the European Union, under the supervision of the European Commission. To paraphrase the words of a Polish politician: "Human rights or death". Either the Union will start protecting human rights, women's rights, LGBT+ rights, or it will cease to exist.

name: Nicola Procaccini (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thought that this debate was an opportunity to deal with sensitive issues such as the expropriation of powers of direction and control by some national parliaments, which in some cases creates scandal and in others does not, depending on the political colour. Instead, we find a list of who would be most affected by the pandemic by its very nature, namely illegal immigrants, some ethnic, gay, lesbian, bisexual, transsexual and intersex minorities... I am sorry, but this craze for creating lists of alleged discrimination is an unacceptable discriminatory reality: all citizens are affected, regardless of ethnic origin and sexual orientation. Unfortunately, it is the usual ideology that imbues the benches to the left of this House. So this debate becomes a missed opportunity, and I'm really sorry about that.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, authoritarianism did not come to Europe with COVID, but, of course, in many countries COVID is being used as an alibi to cut fundamental rights and freedoms. Ensuring that measures against COVID are implemented in a non-discriminatory manner is crucial. That is why we support any proposal that fights against a classist, racist and sexist application of these measures and, therefore, at the time, we denounce the class confinements that were applied in the Community of Madrid. But just as important is to say that this classism, this racism and this sexism were already present in the access to fundamental rights before the pandemic: evictions, the commodization of health, the precariousness of education, the maintenance of thousands of people in irregularity, the sale of residences to vulture funds, energy poverty. Let us not fall into the mistake of thinking that COVID has created these inequalities. The focus needs to be on the fundamental problem: the neoliberal and eco-acid policies that have been imposed for years in the countries of the European Union. We have to get out of this crisis not by cutting rights, but by gaining new rights. That's how we're going to get out of this crisis.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, lockdown has devastated many branches of the economy as a measure. We see the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer. It's not right. That's inadmissible.  Some countries have sought to help their economies by freeing up large amounts of money by central banks. That money would then be borrowed by commercial banks, and then they should lend that money to businesses and citizens. However, if you are about to go bankrupt, if you do not have money, why would a commercial bank lend money to you or your company. Of course he won't, and if he does, he'll borrow on very rigorous terms and high interest rates.  It had to be done the other way around. With helicopter money, central banks needed direct and non-refundable assistance to businesses and individuals and thus the money would not be stuck in the financial system. In the long run, the matter is solved by universal basic income, which aims, therefore, to redirect the wealth of an economy to its citizens in a grant and unconditional way.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, especially at a time of crisis, when our society is in uncharted territory and when our democratic institutions, our rule of law and our fundamental freedoms are under pressure, power needs counter-power. It is precisely then that we need parliaments, and that is precisely when we need the European Parliament. I therefore join all those who have called today to ensure that we can fulfil our democratic task in this House as quickly as possible in a healthy and safe manner. This is important not only for us, but also for the rest of Europe. It is precisely now that we must stand for our principles and defend our rule of law and our controls and safeguards, not simply to put them aside. The rule of law is not an obstacle to an effective approach to the pandemic, but rather a basic condition for an inclusive, democratic and proportionate approach. The measures taken by the Member States must be directly linked to the health crisis, delineated over time, proportionate and regularly monitored by experts and parliaments. This week, with the agreement on the MFK, we showed how important we consider the rule of law to be. Member States that undermine the rule of law will now have to do without European subsidies. Especially in times of crisis, people – and those in power – show their true nature. So let us, too, make it very clear in this time of crisis that this commitment to the rule of law is more than just words for us, and that action must also come from it.

name: Петър Витанов (S&D).
text: The crown crisis exposed the autocratic features of certain governments in some Member States. In Bulgaria, for example, the government forgot that healthcare is a fundamental human right and in its failure to deal with the crown crisis deprived many Bulgarian citizens of it. Under the pretext of fighting Kovid, we have witnessed some decidedly questionable practices and frequent abuse of the extraordinary powers of the executive, such as extraordinary situations, restriction of freedom of movement, restriction of the right to assembly, restriction of the media, even suspension of parliaments and administration by decrees of ministers, without any democratic control.  It is noticeable that some rulers use the coronavirus as an excuse as a convenient excuse to concrete their power in an undemocratic way, including when protests against them erupt and they are banned or restricted on their own terms. I therefore believe that it is crucial to monitor and compare different approaches in view of their impact on democracy, on respect for fundamental human rights and on the rule of law.  All this also raises some questions for the European Commission that I would like to ask. First, will the Commission continue to monitor the situation, including through a comprehensive assessment to be made public? Will the Commission provide further guidance to stimulate exchanges of positive, best practices? And thirdly, in establishing that some measures are not proportionate, not democratic, will the Commission take action to comply with European Union law and what will they be? Thank you.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, European democracy, the democratic rule of law is the business of all Europeans. That is why this Parliament is so important now. And that is why the work of the European Commission is so important and that is why its role is so important, Commissioner Reynders. We need transparency and we need to avoid any arbitrariness, because it is the discretion of the ultra-reinforced executives to know why and who is behind each of the measures restricting our freedoms, because they are touching the very heart of the democratic rule of law. Bad decisions, toxic exercise of power are especially negative and poisonous right now, and the temptation of populism is also stronger. That is why we need the exercise of this Parliament. And that is why we will not be docile in the face of any arbitrariness or discretion, either of the Executives, the Executive and the Presidency of this Parliament. We need to be able to do our job fully because it's more important right now. That's right, yes. And another issue that is very important ⸺not yet said⸺: there are more than 200,000 Europeans, according to official data, who have died from coronavirus in Europe. More than 200 000, let's put it in this Parliament. And that is why we are going to demand in this Parliament a committee to objectively study, technically, what happened on the first wave. And that is why this Parliament is going to say that it will not let its guard down in the face of any temptation to weaken our rule of law, and it will demand it. And that is why we need this Parliament absolutely active, with all its powers, with all our capacity for representation, with all our capabilities as a Parliament. And that's why we need to indicate what the actual data is. In my country there are 20,000 dead who have not even been counted.

name: Diana Riba i Giner (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, staying home in pandemic times has reduced the spread of COVID, but for millions of women being at home is not synonymous with security, but violence.  According to WHO data, threats and violence against women by their partners in Europe have increased by 60%. As the United Nations points out, violence against women is the most widespread human rights violation in the world, and the pandemic has only aggravated it.  On the other hand, in countries such as Poland, Romania or Slovakia, the pandemic is used to restrict women's sexual and reproductive rights. We must combat this injustice on the streets of Warsaw, yes, but also by legislating in this chamber.  For all this, we are urged by a monitoring mechanism for democracy and the rule of law and fundamental rights which protects women's rights in particular, and also for the Commission to introduce gender-based violence into the European crime list.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: Mr President, emergency laws and regulations restricting citizens' fundamental rights should only be used in real emergencies, such as war and other serious crises. Is there a real emergency in the EU? COVID—19 is a relatively mild virus that has only been able to lead to a crisis because the capacity of care is not calculated for pandemics and governments are not sufficiently prepared to manage a crisis. Unfortunately, as a result, it is now necessary to intervene more quickly than would have been necessary with proper emergency preparation. In order to prevent history from repeating itself, action must be taken not only within governments, but also within the EU institutions. The next crisis could be a pandemic, but also a severe recession, civil unrest or even war. Governments need to take this into account when setting policies and budgets and build in buffers for emergencies so that we rarely, if ever, have to rely on emergency interventions in the future, as real emergencies are fortunately rare.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Albert Camus wrote in The Plague, ‘I have no idea what’s awaiting me, or what will happen when all this ends. For the moment I know this; there are sick people and they need curing.’ This is a basic truth. We should remind the national governments for some of them think too much about how all this will end for them. During the uncertainty caused by the pandemic, there is an especially great potential for abuse of the human tragedy for political ends and here lies an additional danger, the danger that emergency measures taken during the second wave of the pandemic can lead to further and harsher abuse of the circumstances for political means. We must not allow that. We have to be strong, we have to be united in countering any temptation to curtail the rights of citizens in the name of fighting the current plague. COVID-19 must not become a convenient justification for cracking down on social protests, limiting the role of the opposition and holding free and fair elections.  At this moment, we need to consolidate all our efforts towards curing the sick and also towards defending our fundamental values against power grabs by unscrupulous politicians and here we must be vigilant and ensure that in this House the rule of law is respected.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The resolution on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on democracy raises an essential issue, the role that power plays in democracy. The question of its responsibilities and borders.  In an emergency situation such as a pandemic, there are restrictions on citizens' rights, prohibitions on assembly, travel bans. This makes citizens even more vulnerable to power.  The test of whether a power is truly democratic is its behaviour in such an emergency. The question is: are politicians not using this moment to trample on the rights and dignity of citizens? Some governments in the Union have failed this test. I will give you an example from recent weeks. The United Right Government, which is forcing women in Poland to protest desperately in defence of their most fundamental rights right now, during the second wave of pandemies. But I have no doubt: this power will not win with women. In a democracy, power is meant to serve citizens, not the other way around. What is happening in Poland today is a harbinger of the end of a certain stage. The women's revolution will change Poland to a better, respectful of human rights, open, modern, tolerant and respectful of all its citizens and citizens, endowed with a sense of humor, distance to itself, over-retooling and obsessed with its own. Democracy is a woman. Great respect for all the protesters in these difficult times. You are hope. You have shown that democracy is stronger than coronavirus.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: We will now continue the debate on the oral question to the Commission - Impact of the measures introduced in relation to Covid19 on democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs - (O-000065/2020 - B9-0023/20) (2020/2790(RSP))

name: Geoffroy Didier (PPE).
text: Madam President, the consequences of the health crisis are numerous in many respects, they are shaking up democracies in the way they organise the rights and duties of every citizen, but also in their internal functioning. The very fact that the vast majority of Members of the European Parliament are, in fact, placed under house arrest in the exercise of their mission, that they can no longer vote in the Chamber, that they can no longer meet, poses a real political problem. This is at a time when we need Europe more than ever. We are the continent most affected by the epidemic, we are the continent most affected by the economic crisis, the terrorist threat is at our borders and on our territory. We therefore have an urgent duty to find solutions that allow us to fully exercise our mission, or at least as abnormally as possible. This is while, as we know, the health crisis will last not only a few more weeks, but several months. So I propose that we put in place stricter sanitary conditions to allow us to carry out our mission in collaboration with our teams. There may, for example, be antigenic tests that give results in fifteen minutes and which the European Parliament can obtain. We could also give COVID a negative test certificate before entering the Chamber. In short, if we are agile and inventive, solutions exist. We must be particularly intransigent on the respect of health guidelines, but we must also be demanding of popular expectations, which, especially in times of crisis, wish that democracy can produce its full effects.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that the pandemic has made extraordinary measures absolutely necessary to protect the lives of European citizens, measures which have often, unfortunately, as we know, also concerned restrictions on individual freedoms. This is a condition of absolute exceptionality, which has been made indispensable by the spread of the virus and the need to save human lives.  But if this is acceptable, if this is understandable, if that is even right, the abuses of power that are taking place, Madam President, and which concern you, I would like to stress this very strongly, particularly for women, are not acceptable, because it is now proven that in many countries access to legal and safe abortion and to all treatment that is linked to sexual health and reproductive health is denied or hindered. There are countries, such as Poland, which have taken advantage of this emergency situation to restrict the freedom of their citizens, and that, Madam President, is totally unacceptable.

name: Frances Fitzgerald (PPE).
text: – Madam President, COVID-19 has been and continues to be a stress test for democracies, the resilience of national safeguards and, importantly, the rule of law. COVID-19 impacts on fundamental rights of citizens and democracy. A crisis such as the scale of this pandemic brings unprecedented challenges in every area, including the rule of law. We must – as politicians, as governments, as NGOs – be extremely alert and willing to interrupt and challenge any violations of these across the EU. A pandemic such as this impacts disproportionately and differentially on women, on gender issues, on minorities and immigrants and those on the margins of society. Women and girls are disproportionately at risk during this pandemic as, during lockdowns, they can be exposed to abusers for long periods of time with no availability of social or institutional support. The risk of child sexual exploitation has, sadly, further increased as have the opportunities for online harassment and disinformation. Undoubtedly, this crisis has brought about the best in many countries, including here in the EU. We’ve seen good leadership, but strongman politics and authoritarianism can take hold. Further restrictive measures must always be accompanied by proper information, education and widespread consultation. Democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law, are at the core of our societies. They cannot and should not be jeopardised by this pandemic.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Madam President. The pandemic has cured our democratic lives. We have no better proof than the fact that the plenary session is taking place virtually, remotely, today. Fortunately, democracy lives on, but it is important for it to find a meaningful life so that we limit democratic institutions only to the extent necessary and within a predefined time. These principles must apply to the work of all parliaments in Europe. At the same time, the pandemic shows how vulnerable we are. In addition to the virus that attacks our bodies, the virus has spread massively in recent months, attacking and destroying the proven information, facts and scientific knowledge that we rely so heavily on to find the right political decisions. The fight against disinformation suddenly has a different, urgent dimension when we see how lies on social media about guaranteed coronavirus drugs, the use of masks or vaccinations, are destroying people's health and lives. Misinformation can kill. And we in Europe must defend ourselves together in the face of increasing infodémia. Our citizens have the right to honest and truthful information from their governments, the media, but also on social networks. Online must pay in the same way as in traditional media that facts always take precedence over lies. And every social network user in Europe deserves the same level of protection from manipulative content. Democracy needs digital platforms that are accountable and transparent to its users. Not one that destroys fair political debate and spreads misinformation, regardless of its implications for human health.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, at exceptional times it is when the full exercise of this Parliament is most necessary as a guarantor of democracy. Madam President, COVID has hit our health hard, with hundreds of thousands of deaths among our loved ones, and also our economy, with the loss of millions of jobs. But this pandemic has tested the resilience of our democracies and our institutions. The health crisis cannot serve as an excuse to weaken our rule of law and degrade our values. The exceptionality of the pandemic must lead national governments, now more than ever, to strengthen, to protect our fundamental rights and the balance of powers; more parliamentary scrtrolling; to combat misinformation, guaranteeing freedom of expression, the right to information and media pluralism, and not quite the opposite. It is worrying to see governments of consolidated democracies trying to undermine judicial independence, making decisions that may limit or censor the right to information, or using exception measures to prevent parliamentary scrtrolling. Ladies and gentlemen, this is happening today within the Union. Europe cannot return to the dark truth committees. Europe must stand firm in defending freedom and the rule of law, and we must defeat the virus together, without our democracies regressing. We are not only playing European funds for health, economic and social recovery. We are playing the health and quality of democracy.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, do you know what is stronger than the coronavirus? Love. The love of people who are on the front line and working for us. This debate was supposed to be about fundamental rights, and do you know how many health professionals have taken their holidays in recent days? Do you know how many paramedics who work on the front line every day, like me, closed people's eyes because these people are dying? Every day these people die and no one asks the paramedics if they have time to cry, no one asks if they have time for family, no one asks if they just have time to shop. They go to work, they go to work with COVID-19, with temperature, they go to work on Saturdays and Sundays, they serve twelve hours of service. And I have not once heard anyone in this chamber say to the medics in the European Union: 'Thank you'.  Dear colleagues, we did not cause the coronavirus. It's the Chinese flu, China didn't inform us, we can only call for a proper investigation. But at the moment, if we are talking about rights, let us talk about the rights of those who are on the front line, they most deserve it. And dear medics and all those who help, I thank you from the bottom of my heart for all of us.

name: Sven Simon (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, many members have already mentioned this: most parliaments in the world have found solutions that uphold the rule of law, in line with this resolution. This does not apply to the European Parliament. The European Parliament has become a lawless area. The rule of law no longer applies here. Speeches on a point of order have been banned in principle, and the current violation of Rule 156 of the Rules of Procedure has already been mentioned. On 27 October, the President decided to hold the meetings only from a distance. There is no legal basis for this. The fact that we are still here today, however, grotesquely ignores the President's decision, but it continues to be enduring. It was never withdrawn. There is sheer arbitrariness here. We do not know whether or not the plenary will take place in November. In fact, according to the decision, no one should be here today.  Ladies and gentlemen, if we do not oppose this decision by the President of 27 October, if we also take legal action if we do not maintain the heart of parliamentary democracy, the centre of European public opinion, this plenary, then we will lose all credibility on the rule of law in Europe and in the world. (Applause)

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let me, first of all, thank you again for the debate we have just held this morning and be sure that the Commission will continue to monitor the measures taken by Member States in the fight against COVID-19. We will continue to monitor closely the application of emergency measures in practice and their impact on the rule of law, on fundamental rights, including measures that could go beyond what is proportionate, and finally, their impact on EU law. In particular, we check whether the measures adopted lead to possible non-application of national legislation transposing EU law. In its role as guardian of the treaties, the Commission will not hesitate to take the necessary measures, as we have done in the past. We have expressed, also before this House, our serious concerns raised, in particular, by measures taken in Hungary under the state of alert declared in March. Now that a state of alert has again been introduced, we will remain vigilant and closely monitor the application of emergency powers in practice. On 30 October, the Commission launched an infringement procedure related to the new asylum procedures introduced as a response to the COVID—19 pandemic. We are concerned that these procedures prevent effective access to the asylum procedure and infringe the fundamental right to asylum guaranteed by the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The COVID-19 pandemic has compounded existing inequalities, especially among vulnerable groups such as marginalised Roma communities, and elderly people. Limited access to healthcare, low income, precarious job and housing situations and lower health outcomes make too many members of these groups more vulnerable in times of pandemic.  With schools closed, too many Roma children living in remote areas have no access to online learning and missed school for months. This is unacceptable, as the Commission responded from the very outbreak of the crisis. For instance, in April, Commissioners Dalli, Kyriakides and Schmit sent a letter to the relevant ministers in each Member State emphasising the need for specific measures for those groups in the context of the COVID-19 crisis. In parallel, we drew Member States' attention to the funds available under the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative and the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative Plus, and initiated a dialogue on how to better address the specific needs of the most vulnerable where this is possible. Moreover, the Commission recently adopted, reformed and strengthened its EU-Roma strategic framework for equality, inclusion and participation, and has adopted today its first lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans(gender), intersex and/or queer (LGBTIQ) equality strategy, both reflecting the new needs emerging from the COVID-19 pandemic. This monitoring by the Commission will continue until all emergency measures are fully revoked. And we will continue to publish our analysis of these measures in our reports on the rule of law, as in the report on the Charter of Fundamental Rights, as I announced earlier, following the strategy that will be adopted this year, again.  We will continue to publish recommendations or guidelines when necessary and we will continue our work to exchange best practices, as we have done, particularly with the Ministers of Justice, on the fight against domestic violence, which is on the rise during the pandemic. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to reiterate that this debate is welcome because it is important to maintain a democratic debate on our response to the challenges raised by the COVID-19 crisis, particularly with regard to respect for our common values. Control by national parliaments is very important and, as you know, the functioning of national parliaments is not easy to organise during the pandemic, you are also aware of this when it comes to ensuring the proper functioning of your assembly. In these difficult times, the joint commitment of all EU institutions to respecting fundamental values throughout the European Union is essential. Once again, I would like to thank you, once again, for your commitment in this regard.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The amendments will be voted on today and the final vote will take place tomorrow. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Andrus Ansip (Renew)
text: Writing. – In times of the health crisis caused by COVID-19, people's fundamental rights and freedoms must also be respected. Combating the virus cannot be a justification for limiting people's democratic freedoms. All measures taken to protect public health must be fit for purpose and proportionate. The implementation of disproportionate measures can have devastating consequences for people's mental health. Such measures may also threaten democracy and the rule of law. The measures taken must not harm our people more than the virus.

name: Άννα-Μισέλ Ασημακοπούλου (PPE)
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, among the many challenges due to the pandemic, we are also called upon to manage issues relating to the balance between the necessary preventive measures but the necessary safeguarding of the democratic rights of citizens. At the plenary session of 17 April 2020, in the EP Resolution on coordinated EU action to combat the pandemic and its consequences, we condemned as completely incompatible with European values some of the extraordinary measures taken by some Member States. In the context of the work of the 130th Meeting of Foreign Ministers of the Member States of the Council of Europe, a Declaration was adopted on 4.11.2020 on the defence of democracy, the rule of law and human rights in times of pandemic, the "Athens Declaration". In it, the CoE recognised the dramatic consequences of the pandemic, which in many cases overcame obvious health and economic challenges, jeopardising values such as the rule of law, fundamental rights, but also democracy itself. Respect for these timeless values cannot be undermined by the Member States and Greece, which "gave birth" to the Republic, could only be a pioneer in this. I therefore call on you not to allow the Republic to be quarantined!

name: Dace Melbārde (ECR)
text: in writing. – The Covid-19 pandemic and the subsequent fallout is unprecedented for people, countries and their economies. Unfortunately, in many ways this crisis has also dented our democratic processes. I would like to applaud the impeccable work of our journalists and media organisations in providing up-to-date and important information to the people and and in that way contributing in the fight against the virus — and the disinformation about Covid-19. As has been stated many times, the best way to fight disinformation is through adequate funding for quality media so as to ensure that independent journalism and media pluralism is flourishing, not stifled. But whilst the media consumption has been on the rise throughout the lockdowns, media organisations are struggling due to subdued incomes from advertising and the general lack of funding which has been ailing them well before the pandemic. Failed media cannot be resurrected or bailed out like other industries. It is high time for Member States and the EU to address this emergency in the sector so as to ensure that media organisations can continue without undue restraints their important social and democratic function, and that they emerge from the crisis stronger and more resilient.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – With the COVID-19 outbreak, Member States were obliged to take action in view of the reduction in contagion. Some measures may be questionable as to their health effectiveness and, unfortunately, can have a negative impact on people's lives by restricting their rights, freedoms and guarantees. It is an example of this to use the state of emergency. We believe that the measures taken must be in line with the actual needs and challenges posed by the situation. In this sense, we need measures that stimulate individual protection, promote the pedagogy of protection and ensure health security conditions so that life can continue in its multiple dimensions. It is necessary to strengthen the responsiveness of public health services, safety in the functioning of schools, homes, public transport, cultural and sports facilities and equipment. The way may not be to suspend, prohibit or prevent activities or events or restrict the exercise of rights, freedoms and guarantees.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the information provided by Cristian-Silviu Buşoi on the Debate on the report on the proposal for the EU Health Action Programme 2021-2027 ('EU for Health') on behalf of the Committee on Public Health and Food Safety (COM(2020) )0405 - C9-0152/2020 - 2020/0102(COD)) (A9-0196/2020). I would like to inform Members that none of the debates in this meeting will be heard on the basis of an application and that we will not accept blue cards and points of order.  In addition, speeches can be expected from Parliament's contact offices in the Member States via a remote link.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, at Union level we had had three stand-alone health programmes before the proposal in 2018 to have it incorporated in the 4th health programme under the ESF+ as a strand, in times where at least 70% of our population ask for and expect more and bolder EU intervention on health. Myself, at the time I was expressing concerns at the budgetary dilution and asked for the EU health programme to be an independent instrument and a central keystone of EU policy.  The COVID-19 crisis has clearly proven the European Union’s need for well-defined and adequately financed policy instruments. Moreover, with the rising expectation from our citizens, from the Union and from us, the policymakers, in the field of health – in particular now, given the current crisis – I am proud to witness that Commissioner Ursula von der Leyen, and especially Commissioner Kyriakides, have delivered both on citizens’ expectations and on addressing the challenges we are facing. I would like to take this opportunity to thank you, Commissioner, in the plenary of this House. The EU4Health programme will stand as the 4th health programme of the Union as a separate instrument for the 2021-2027 period. As a direct consequence of COVID-19, a stand-alone programme was proposed aimed at strengthening EU health systems and health care with an initial robust budget of EUR 9.4 billion. Compared to the 3rd programme for health, the EU4Health programme will deliver on many more actions to support Member States in the field of health and complement their efforts in reforming their health systems to become more resilient. As the rapporteur, when drafting the initial report, I emphasised the importance of the fact that the EU4Health programme is more than just a response to the COVID-19 crisis and it should deliver not only on short-term crisis management, but also on long-term objectives in ensuring the development of strong and resilient health systems in the Member States, and should address long-term challenges such as cancer, the burden of chronic diseases, and of course, mental health and ageing, vaccine hesitancy and equal access during medicine shortages.  One of the top priorities I had as rapporter was cancer and the EU4 Health Programme will strengthen the European Union’s fight against cancer with concrete actions to address the lack of screening, early diagnosis and access to treatment and care and in synergy with the Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan.  Another priority for us, the European Parliament team working on this file, was to digitalise health care, in particular through the creation and application of European e—health records and support for the creation and use of the future European health data space platform.  The programme will not only deliver on fighting cancer, but also on digitalisation and forthcoming worrying realities – future pandemics and health threats – by working in synergy with other programmes, instruments and funds like the Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan, Horizon Europe, and especially the mission for cancer, the Digital Agenda and the RRF (Recovery and Resilience Fund). After the vote in committee, we clearly showed that the European Parliament stands for improving the health of our citizens by health promotion and a person-centred approach to address communicable and non-communicable diseases, with a focus on chronic diseases, early screening, prevention, future development of European reference networks, addressing vaccine hesitancy, shortage of medicines and health inequalities. Therefore, I am looking forward to the vote today in the plenary and I expect to have a clear and strong mandate to start the negotiations. Regarding the budget, the envelope was cut by EUR 1.7 billion in July and in the committee we restored the amount completely to show that we aim for an increase, and with this commitment we are here today in the plenary. An agreement was reached this week with a major increase up to EUR 5.1 billion for health compared to the cut in July, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank my party, the PPE, and to thank the European Parliament negotiating team for their support. This increase is a triumph for all of us.  Compared with the 3rd health programme, we have a robust budget that will come in support of Member States. This budget will be able to complement Member States’ efforts and national programmes, and in synergy with other instruments will deliver on improving the wellbeing of our citizens by addressing health inequalities, strengthening health care systems, support for digitalisation of health care through the European e-health record and the European health data space. And of course, what was extremely important and I mentioned earlier, last but not least, really fight cancer.  I’d like to take this opportunity to thank my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, for their work. It was an extraordinary team, very dedicated and I’m really grateful, colleagues, for your support and collaboration. We succeeded on a fast-track to deliver what will be the most ambitious and well-funded health programme of the Union to date. I’m really grateful and I’m grateful to the Commission for all their efforts and the good cooperation. I’m looking forward to a successful vote tomorrow and a very interesting debate today, and this will be a starting point for what will be a European Union for health, with real achievements, in order to respond to European citizens’ expectations.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is indeed a great pleasure to join you to discuss the EU4Health programme. This programme is the key financial tool to help protect our citizens’ health, to fight major public threats like COVID-19, and of course to reinforce Europe’s health systems. The Commission greatly appreciates the efforts that have gone into preparing today’s draft report. In particular, however, I would like to thank the rapporteur Cristian Buşoi and the shadow rapporteurs and of course MEP Ştefănuță, as Budget Committee rapporteur.  These are very difficult times for our citizens, for businesses, for our Member States, for our European health care systems. The worldwide surge of cases is extremely worrying. Over eight million cases have been confirmed in the EU alone. Hospital admissions are increasing every day. Pandemic related health issues are growing. Too many people have lost their loved ones. Too many are suffering and every day when we hear numbers these numbers are about people. They are about families, they are about life stories.  In this context I am delighted that in the trilogues for the Next Generation EU, and our future MFF, this essential programme for the health of our citizens has emerged stronger and reinforced to EUR 5.1 billion. I know that this House has played a key role in this effort and I want to thank everyone, especially Cristian Buşoi in particular, for sharing our vision and for fighting our corner on this. I think actually I have been losing my voice over the last week from, at the beginning, speaking with everyone to thank them for this effort and yesterday from the excitement of hearing the news. This programme will be a fundamental element of our work towards building a genuine and strong European health union by strengthening our crisis preparedness and management and the resilience of our health systems. COVID has shown us the importance of working together to reinforce our crisis readiness actions. This implies sufficient funding at EU level and building synergies with other instruments such as rescEU for stockpiling products needed for crisis.  We also need to take forward the digital transformation of the health sector to build on the positive momentum and more generally, we need to strengthen the EU’s ability to support and complement Member States’ programmes and actions.  The public needs to hear a clear message that public health is a priority area for Europe’s recovery. At the beginning of this crisis citizens across Europe were all saying, ‘where is the EU? We need more EU in public health’ and I believe that together, Parliament and the Commission, we have shown that we have been listening. We have been listening that targeted investment in crisis preparedness and stronger health systems are essential for the future. We are mobilising all possible resources to strengthen our defences, including crucially funding, which in many cases is a determinant of feasibility.  I am glad that we agree on the basic rationale and policy objectives of the future EU4Health programme. The amendments proposed take into account the COVID-19 challenges and other public health needs. The Commission notes Parliament’s wish for a more inclusive governance framework and we will be doing this. This is clearly an area that we will be discussing, though we should avoid adding anything to the governance, and I stress this, that would be overly burdensome or introduce mechanisms that would prevent efficient preparation and implementation of our programme. We have built a long tradition of consulting extensively with stakeholders and we place a high value on the input received. I am personally committed to maintaining this approach during the preparatory phase of the work plans as well as their implementation. We are partners in this. The gravity of the current health crisis calls for swift conclusion of the negotiations. It calls for a programme that complements the other important strands of EU action to strengthen the resilience of our health systems and our preparedness and response capacity to cross-border health threats.  I am convinced that an agreement in the first reading is both possible and is absolutely necessary. We will do our utmost to facilitate negotiations between co-legislators. What is now required is close cooperation and the swift agreement between Parliament and the Council to ensure EU4Health can deliver its full potential.  I fully count on your support to take this forward, and what I would like to share with you in ending is that when we put this programme forward, and we called it EU4Health, I felt from that moment on that we had true partners within this institution and having achieved the proposed increase of the budget, I now know that we’re going to be partners hand in hand with this because this is what citizens expect from us and this is what we need to deliver.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, I am a little nervous because I have listened to Commissioner Kyriakides' speech and because everyone in this room currently has people, friends, relatives who are in hospitals, affected by the pandemic we are in, unfortunately. Well, I speak for my colleagues in the budget and I am excited that we have achieved a fantastic thing: when Madam President Ursula von der Leyen presented us with the Green Pact, she said that this is our time to send a man to the moon, "our man to the Moon moment", and when you, Mrs Kyriakides, presented us with the EU4Health, we hoped the same thing that this is a time to send a man to the moon. I had hoped that by seeing that initial budget of almost 10 billion, I was very disappointed when it was dropped to 1.7 by the Council. Now I am proud of all those who participated and made it at least 5.1 billion. This shows that we in Brussels are actually taking seriously the health threats that this continent is going through and the aggressive interaction of man with nature and the climate change that affects us.  The most important lesson we have learned from this crisis is that when we invest in science, in research, we win, we make the impossible possible. In less than a year we are able to have a vaccine. The man on the moon was not sent with speeches, with big words, the man on the moon was sent with 20 billion dollars invested in nine years in the Apollo program.  Speeches don't build hospitals, speeches don't provide protective material for doctors, speeches don't save people, words need to be reinforced by big budgets. That is why I look at you with confidence, Mrs Kyriakides, and invite you to write history together for European health.

name: Chrysoula Zacharopoulou
text: rapporteur for FEMM opinion. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to welcome this ambitious programme towards a Europe of health on board. As we face a pandemic of unprecedented magnitude, women caregivers are on the front line in all European countries. We owe them our salvation. But their commitment makes yet another reality unbearable: inequalities and disparities in access to care between women and men. There is therefore an urgent need for action. We need to advance knowledge of gender and gender issues and integrate them into the EU4Health programme, in the areas of prevention, diagnosis, treatment and research. The specificities of each gender must also be taken into account in order to contribute to the information and education of the population and caregivers. Commissioner, dear Stella, talking about women's health is not possible without integrating sexual and reproductive health issues and sexuality education.
