These rights are the primary condition for women's emancipation. It is a public health issue, but it is also a question of dignity. Yet conservatism in Europe and around the world continues to attack women's bodies - the latest example in Poland. In Europe, can we accept IVG tourism? Can we accept that European women are putting their lives at risk by resorting to clandestine abortions? Ladies and gentlemen, we must support the amendments on sexual and reproductive health. Commissioner, in this Europe of values and the Europe of health we want, health and rights are inseparable for all.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to offer my sincere congratulations to the rapporteur, Christian Buoi, and to all those who have otherwise contributed. We really have a good approach to this new major health programme. And a big thank you to Manfred Weber and the others who helped us to have a decent financial endowment now. We have ten times more money than in the current period. That is not quite as much as Parliament and the Commission would have liked, but there are ten times more opportunities to help patients in the European Union in concrete terms. And, of course, this is the first thing we are talking about. Everyone should look at the death toll and not just the infections: we have almost four thousand people who died yesterday alone from this pandemic. That is why it is important that we act, but that the right measures are taken, above all in the Member States. And that is why I am wearing a mask in my speech today, because when you speak, something comes out, and that is prevented by a mask. But Christian Buoi is right: we also have to look at the long term. And the issue of cancer is particularly important for the PPE-DE. The Commission has already made a good proposal, and Parliament has improved it once again. We want concrete measures that will lead to fewer cancer cases and better treatment across Europe. Many thanks to all who helped.

name: Sara Cerdas
text: on behalf of the S&D Group- Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Commissioner, Europeans have asked and today this Parliament is responding.  2020 is a historic year, with a pandemic that has exposed the fragility of all the health systems of the countries in this world! In the European Union, health provision is the responsibility of each Member State, which may have been an initial weakness in the response to this pandemic.  The Commission has presented as its answer the most ambitious plan ever for European health, but this Parliament goes further.  We will adopt a programme focused on two fundamental points, so that we do not repeat the mistakes of the past and to ensure a sustainable future.  A health-focused program in all policies and one health.  A programme addressing the main health challenges in relation to communicable diseases and non-communicable diseases. That it empowers the Union's health response and is focused on reducing health inequalities, ensuring universal accessibility to health care and having an approach focused on health promotion and the different aspects of disease prevention. With improvements in health literacy for everyone, leaving no one behind. And also, because this is the year of the pandemic, we learned the lessons.  Because the health of our Union cannot be at 27 speeds, there is a need for greater harmonisation and coordination in response to health crises and, for this, we call for the creation of a European mechanism for responding to threats in public health. We can't wait for another pandemic. We need stress tests, in a controlled manner, to the most diverse health systems of this Union, to identify failures and opportunities with minimum parameters for the health care provided by each of the 27. Scientific evidence tells us that for every euro that is invested in public health interventions, the long-term return is 14 times more. With the conclusion of the negotiations, the budget was thus tripled to EUR 5.1 billion for this programme. Now it's time to multiply it by 14.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, this health crisis has therefore revealed to us the extraordinary fragility of the European Union in terms of public health. Thank you, Commissioner, dear Stella, dear partner, as you say, for listening to us here in this Chamber in April, July and September. Thank you for hearing our calls for a stronger, more responsive and more coordinated Europe of health. The first step has been taken. You lost your voice yesterday, presenting the programme for strengthening the European Union in preparation for health crises. The heads of government must now listen to the citizens' call for a genuine Europe of health and validate the tripling of the health budget - thanks to Nicolae 'tef'nu' and the Committee on Budgets for carrying it. We must promote global health, ensure that the health impact of all European policies - employment, agriculture, transport, education and development - is taken into account. This holistic vision will enable us to achieve our priority goal: reducing health inequalities. In the negotiations with the Council, we will defend our main thematic priorities: an ambitious plan against cancer, the prevention of chronic diseases, the better consideration of rare diseases, the strengthening of europe's drug, but also environmental health, occupational health and sexual and reproductive health. We will also advocate for greater involvement of civil society and patient associations. We all hope for a strong mandate to vote tomorrow, to foreshadow this Europe of health that we want to see develop in the framework of the conference for the future of Europe.

name: Silvia Sardone
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must make this clear: Europe has not focused on health in recent years, unfortunately. Indeed, from 2011 to 2018, the European Commission asked Member States 63 times to cut their health spending. The critical issues linked to this emergency situation and the crisis in the sector therefore arise from problems that you have created and that we are now facing. Among other things, the management of this pandemic, both in the first and second phase, has been confusing, un coordinate and constantly lagging behind in the decisions to be implemented. You have been behind the World Health Organisation in a very bad way. And then we remember the decision of the European Council last July, the decision to reduce funding for the health programme. They have been reduced, or at least this was the proposal in May, from EUR 9.4 billion to EUR 1.67 billion. All this in the middle of a global pandemic. A paradox, of course, of which many should honestly be ashamed. The European Union must understand that it cannot allocate ridiculous budgets to the health challenges we are facing. We also need to change the general philosophy: I see a Europe too focused on chasing the good dreams of every Greta on duty, of every Greta waking up in the morning. But do you realize that the current priority is to save lives and keep the continental health system in place? Now we are looking for a change of line and an attempt to repair the damage done. Well, we welcome it, but there is still much to be done. The Commission's proposal needs to be clarified. And then let me make one thing clear: European money is not yet wasted on absurd funding such as that at the Institute of Virology in Wuhan. Never again, please! Of course, the best possible programme for the health of European citizens must be guaranteed. At a time of health crisis, citizens rightly expect the European Union to take a more active, more serious role, an institution that can really coordinate other states. They want a Europe that pushes for investment in more infrastructure, that promotes the employment of doctors and nurses, that invests in research. Much needs to be changed to ensure a full capacity to proactively respond to needs. Of course, at this time of emergency, the citizens expect something more from Europe. We believe that this plan must increase the security of production, the security of supply and also the distribution of medicines and medical devices, something that we have unfortunately not seen so far, leading to the tragedy of countries that have been refused respirators and not only at the beginning of the pandemic. For example, Italy, my country, has been denied aid for weeks, other than European solidarity! Then Mrs von der Leyen apologised, but frankly we do not expect an apology, we expect the facts, we expect a different Europe. At the same time, European production must be supported, because today, more than ever, dependence on third countries must be reduced for raw materials, medicines, medical devices and much more. We have been dependent on the Asian countries for far too long, and it is not possible to continue in this way. Europe must stop focusing on very expensive projects for an ecological and fragrant world, this is not the time. The health of our citizens must now be prioritised and must not be seen as a nuisance that should not be seriously addressed. In short, Europe is beginning to make Europe, it is really beginning to play a role in the various States. We have not seen her in recent months and, when we saw her, we saw her acting badly and late. We do not need excuses, we need concrete and real measures for the States. We are in a pandemic, Europe is starting to make Europe!

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Mr Rapporteur, Cristian Buoi, with regard to this plan, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner because yesterday I saw your strategy on the European Union for health, and I must admit that there is much in common between what we have been working on on this fourth action programme, EU4Health, and your proposals. I welcome the fact that there are commonalities. You have addressed the problem of stress tests, but you know that this was a request of the Greens and I had asked you a lot on this subject so that we could take stock of the situation and look, in the event of a health crisis, at what is the state of the health systems in different countries, how we can better harmonize, how we can compare different strategies, it is very important to then have appropriate answers. At the same time, normally, eu4Health should improve the management of health crises, make medicines and health products more accessible and improve access to care. We have learned that the budget was voted on in the Budget Committee, and I thank him for that. We MEPs have made sure to impose certain priorities on this programme—framework, in particular through the support and establishment of public institutions—private pharmaceuticals for non-profit, to produce essential medicines that may be lacking at European level. It is a question of regaining health sovereignty. And even now, at the level of the crisis, in some countries, there is a shortage. So it is very important to do that. There is also a lot of talk about the epidemic of cancers, these chronic diseases, and here we are in the process of creating a European Cancer Institute, which will have the task of synthesising existing and future national registers, and which will allow us to know precisely the number of cancers per country, what type of cancer it is, which age group or gender. The axis of prevention is therefore essential. But the best therapy for cancer, let's remember, is first of all not to develop it. And Europe has a responsibility on chemical pollution, on endocrine disruptors, and even on electromagnetic waves. I the so-called I welcome the complementarity between the Commission's strategy and this report, which will define the framework programme.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, first of all, let me express my genuine joy at the increase in the overall budget to EUR 5.1 billion. This is less than was originally proposed by the Commission and as many MEPs imagined, but I think we are starting to come to a situation that will allow us to finance at least some of the priorities sufficiently. As you know, in committee we were forced to make very painful cuts to fit in. Now we're going to have to do them, too, but under less pressure.  On the overall scale and objectives of the programme, I would just like to say that I hope that it will not focus solely on tackling the COVID-19 pandemic or cancer patients. It should be stressed that there are other diseases and other structural problems in the European Union's health system that have been overlooked for decades and which also need to be addressed. I am glad that mr Bușoi's report was adopted practically unanimously and on the basis of a broad political agreement. I hope that this will happen here in plenary.  After the increase in the budget, the question of possible stockpiling still lies ahead. Despite the increase, I would be cautious about introducing it. It is clear that stockpiling is capable of exhausting a significant part of the budget on its own, whatever its form, and I still do not consider the current amount sufficient to implement it. Colleagues, I look forward to the results of the vote and to the upcoming trialogues. We still have a lot of work to do, but the work that Europe needs that can help hundreds, thousands and millions of patients.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: Mr President, health is of great importance to all. The Commission is now taking a step in the right direction by reminding the governments of the Member States that they must cooperate in times of crisis. It also advocates a broad European approach to prevent future health deficits and respond properly to crises. This approach focuses on the COVID–19 crisis. However, crises can occur in many forms. Since there are many – in my opinion too many – people on this planet, we can count on many more crises in the future. This offers bureaucrats, national governments and the EU an excellent opportunity to gain more power, thus risking the democratic rule of law and protecting citizens from abuses of power by the government.  In this respect, the EU must set a good example and show self-control, and above all to monitor the quality of the democratic rule of law in all Member States. Health care is still the primary responsibility of the Member States.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The crisis caused by the coronavirus has highlighted the importance of our health and the impact of health on our lives, the economy and society. We are in the midst of a pandemic, but we must look forward to a new and orderly life. However, this requires ambitious targets, actions and programmes. We can say that there is a need to place more emphasis on health than ever before and to respond much more quickly to unforeseen health threats. Together, the EU For Health programme and the European Health Union presented by the Committee yesterday can open a new chapter in health policy at EU level. It is to be welcomed that the EU for Health has an ambitious financial framework, but I would like to draw attention to the fact that it is essential for the success of the programme that all Member States benefit from the programme to the same extent. Proportional geographical distribution is therefore of key importance.  Finally, as a member of the European People's Party, I am pleased that the European Health Union is a joint inter-parliamentary initiative in which my party family has been actively involved. Improving the health situation is in our common interest in all Member States, which we fully support. However, we must not forget that health is a competence of the Member States and should not be any different in the future.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ensuring the good health and well-being of citizens is one of the most fundamental responsibilities of a society.  The right to physical and mental health is a fundamental human right and every person, without discrimination, has the right to access modern and comprehensive healthcare.  We Socialists and Democrats are convinced that Europe needs stronger and more robust health programmes, both to strengthen the cooperation between the Member States, but also to overcome the common transnational health emergencies such as the present COVID-19 pandemic. The pandemic shows clearly that we need to do more to protect the citizens’ health and we need to do it better. We welcome the EU4Health programme which significantly boosts Europe’s effort to improve the health of all citizens, and to be an important building block for the Health Union. In order to achieve concrete results, we must also fully take into account the underlying root causes that threaten our health. There are important social, economic and societal factors that have a clear impact on our health. Economic inequalities, social factors such as alcohol intake, dietary habits or the exposure to chemicals affect us. These factors must be included in Europe’s actions so we can prevent disease and illness. Therefore we have worked hard to further develop proper health determinants in this regulation. All people have the same right to high quality, safe, accessible and affordable health care.  Finally, I’d like to mention also the tremendous work that my colleague, Sara Cerdas, has done for this programme and who managed to secure the Parliament’s position which contains many of the important wins for Europe’s citizens.

name: Frédérique Ries (Renew).
text: Madam President, I too, of course, would like to welcome the agreement reached the day before yesterday with the Council on the European budget for the next seven years. More than 5 billion euros for health. So, of course, that is half of what we were asking for, The Commission and Parliament, but it is still a revolution, twelve times what was envisaged by the previous Commission. Unfortunately, it took an unprecedented crisis, such as the one we are going through, to make everyone understand the vital, crucial importance of the European link in the protection of health. So it's not just COVID, which my colleagues have already commented extensively on. Personally, I would like to mention a particular subject, a fight that has been going on for several years on the benches of this Parliament, I would like to talk this morning about rare diseases. For these often forgotten patients, hundreds of kilometres from their specialist, sometimes even across the border, we have groped the new tools of a new medicine. I am thinking of online consultations, networking of knowledge, it is the reference networks, or common information platforms, such as Orphanet. These are great tools and I am delighted that the Commission is proposing to expand them, to share them, especially with cancer or wherever it is useful, but not at the expense of rare diseases. These advances are still fragile, they need to be consolidated, their budget strengthened and sanctified. So this is a call I wanted to make this morning: to make the fight against rare diseases a priority is also to fight for the health of all Europeans.

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Madam President, having known 'too late', to have understood 'too late', and to have acted 'too late', is probably, in MacArthur's words, the two words which best sum up the European Union's attitude on the health crisis. As the tsunami arrived, and drastic containment measures were enacted, particularly in China, the European Union was content, at first, to call to order all states that had the common sense to re-establish controls at national borders to guard against and slow the spread of the virus, and to make tutos to wash their hands. But nothing about masks, nothing about test production, nothing about the relocation of our drug lines, so much so that this inertia has thrown many countries, like Italy, into the arms of China. The text before us today is supposed to mark the birth certificate of Europe's health. But this Europe of health has already existed for years, when it came to tapping states into the portfolio by imposing drastic austerity measures on them, especially in public services. On 63 occasions between 2011 and 2018, the European Commission recommended that Member States reduce their public spending on health. Driven by the European Union, Spain itself has reduced its health spending by 11% over the past decade. And today, it is not without a certain cynicism that the Commission is asking Spain to invest in health, precisely to repair structural problems revealed by the epidemic. The European Union is biting its tail by denouncing the evils it has caused itself. In Italy, some EUR 37 billion of health resources have been cut in recent decades. These cuts resulted in a 50% reduction in the number of beds in the hospital sector and the loss of 70,000 intensive care units. If public health as such is to remain the exclusive competence of States, we are obviously in favour of cooperation between sovereign nations in the face of the pandemic, especially in the financing of research projects, the sums to be unlocked are obviously considerable. But for this cooperation to be effective, it must be organized in the most flexible way possible, between states, rather than being placed under the aegis of a centralized and bureaucratic body. That is the whole point of a Europe à la carte and the projects we are defending.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is sad that it took a pandemic to realise that we need a common health programme. And in this health programme, which is very good, I miss the consistent 'one health' approach, because only in a healthy environment do healthy people exist. I would like to focus on paragraph 7, namely the threat posed by antibiotic-resistant germs. This is addressed, but in my view far too hesitant. For example, I do not see stricter rules for animal husbandry. The example of Sweden shows that more animal welfare is also very much less antibiotic use.  And I call on you to finally work to ensure that environmental criteria are included in Good Manufacturing Practice (GHP), which applies worldwide. At the moment, sewage is leaking into the rivers in Indian production facilities. It is only a matter of time before we have severe antibiotic-resistant germs that can trigger the next pandemic. Please act very quickly!

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the consequences of years of disinvestment in public health services, to open the way to the commercialisation of the sector and the business of the disease, are now exposed to evidence with the COVID-19 pandemic. The European Union has responsibilities on this path. It was imposed, through the Stability Pact and its substitutes, such as the country recommendations, under the European Semester, cuts in health expenditure, decrease in public sector professionals, degradation of their working conditions. Now, this program is not enough not to look bad in the picture. Not only does it fall short of what would be demanded, but it opens up some wicked paths.  We have tried to work to correct some of its most negative aspects and some shortcomings.  While respecting national sovereignty and competences, this programme should focus resources on public health systems, support investments in means of prevention, diagnosis, treatment, infrastructure and professional equipment, support the development of drug policies focused on patient needs, accessibility, security of supply, freed from the constraints of the pharmaceutical industry.

name: Antoni Comín i Oliveres (NI).
text: – Madam President, the health systems of the Member States face immense challenges: increasing life expectancy and, therefore, chronicity, noncommunicable diseases — cancer, in particular — rare diseases, old and new infectious diseases such as COVID, or mental illness, health inequalities between countries, between regions, between social classes, between genders , which confront us with the problem of social determinants of health, the impact of environmental degradation — to name just the most important ones.  And to meet these challenges we need research, more research, from the One Health paradigm; promotion and prevention; truly believe in the concept of health in all policies; and, of course, health capacities must be matched in the field of professionals, in medical technologies, in access to therapeutic innovations, etc.  If we think and address these instruments and strategies at European level, we will move faster and go further. We need to build a European health policy and the EU4Health programme is a step in the right direction.

name: Радан Кънев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, people's health and life are once again number 1 on our agenda. And if in the spring in Eastern Europe we were poorly affected, if with us the pandemic was more of a cause for bragging rights and for abuse of power, then today it develops on a frightening scale and shows the unpreparedness of our institutions. In Bulgaria, in my homeland, infection and mortality are at the levels of Italy and Spain from the spring, and the victims are the ones that are most needed in our society - doctors, nurses, teachers, parents. Europe has shown that if it is united, it can also help financially make up for losses where the passivity and momentum of governments have not done so, and commit to opening borders to professions and goods without which we cannot. Today, people expect clear rules and criteria for protecting citizens, an honest market for medicines, guarantees that financial aid goes to those in need, not to buy elections. Our greatest success and hope is the development of a vaccine by a small, innovative European company, with the crucial help of European innovation programmes, in partnership with industry leaders. Good luck showing the importance of investing in science, and our key task is to get this vaccine to the citizens of Europe with strict order and clear rules. Thank you.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. It's impossible to sum up years of struggle, to condense it into one minute. I would therefore like to express my thanks now to all the professional organisations, the political groups in the European Parliament and now the European Commission, for their contribution to finally ingesting the creation of a European Health Union. We have been fighting for it for many years and I am proud of the Social Democratic Group for being the first to embrace our proposal. For me, as a Hungarian, the starting point was that I wanted to fight for the same number of opportunities for access to health services as for a citizen living in a small village in Kübekház. That is why we are fighting for the European Health Union, and I am pleased that the Commissioner has also sided with her. So let us take concrete steps.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, intensive care units throughout the European Union are 'beating red'. Due to the tragic shortcomings, doctors are again called upon to decide who will live and who will die. Civil governments and the European Union are defending its commodity health and competitive operation for the benefit of the groups, which has cost hundreds of thousands of deaths. Your celebrations of the vaccine cannot hide the fierce competition of pharmaceutical companies, which are incompatible with the social good of health and reserve contract terms unknown and dangerous to the people. In groups and banks you give EUR 1.7 trillion, but for health you foresee only EUR 9 billion, which will not be made available to public structures either but will be made available for further commercialisation and public-private partnerships, while the people will pay handsomely.  Here and now to order private clinics and join the national planning without compensation. Ensure surgeries, tests and tests for all diseases. Mass recruitment of health workers, the opening of intensive care units and the implementation of disease prevention measures in workplaces, nursing homes and public transport.

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the new health programme is a step forward in the construction of Europe. It proves once again that we are not just an Economic and Monetary Union, but a real union of people and for people. Strengthening the Union's health skills, which COVID-19 has shown to be so essential, will benefit us in articulating policies aimed at preventing and combating diseases, including health. It will also ensure the best cooperation in scientific research, from the fundamental to clinical research.  I would like to welcome the announcement of the establishment of a European Biomedical Research Agency. It's a measure I've been defending personally for a long time.  It will also be crucial to create a European health database. Our populations face similar problems. From cancer to cardiovascular disease, it makes sense that we share knowledge in search of solutions that will serve everyone. Respecting the confidentiality of our citizens and taking steps to ensure this confidentiality, we have everything to gain from a common health data space.

name: César Luena (S&D).
text: – Mr President, health is one of the issues of greatest concern to citizens, according to the Eurobarometer, and the right to health protection is also contained in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, in Article 35. I am pleased to see that the budget heading for this programme has tripled and we are going to reach EUR 5.1 billion.  We have five health challenges: overcoming inequalities, improving crisis preparedness, strengthening the Union industry by innovating and supporting business competition, addressing environmental challenges related to health and substances and pharmaceuticals, and leading the digital transformation of health systems. I ask for support for my group's amendments calling for stress testing in health systems, specifically assessing the ability of health institutions to deal with scenarios such as the current, high-pressure one. Finally, I call on the European Commission because we need to have a system or unit for the detection, control and monitoring of zoonotic processes with sufficient resources so that situations such as the current one or possible new threats, such as that of mink in Denmark, are under effective control.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by When the Commission came out in May this year with a draft eu's own health programme for the next seven years, we had the first wave of pandemies. After only a few weeks of fighting COVID-19, it was clear to everyone that we lacked the right tools and resources, including financial resources, in this fight. Only the last cynic can say that the health care system can function by the very idea. No, you need money.  As the European Parliament, we wanted more resources for the Europe for Health programme than the Council, fortunately, in the negotiations we managed to secure a large amount of concrete money for the programme. It's a good start. Citizens' health is invaluable and cannot be saved.  COVID-19 has also shown us the strength and importance of European solidarity. We are much more effective in solidarity. By sticking to national selfishness, we lose. We learned from the solidarity lesson. I am firmly built when, now, in the second wave, the Member States are helping themselves. Here I thank the German authorities for the help offered in the fight for the health of patients across Europe. Unfortunately, Polish government does not accept this assistance for political reasons, but we in Silesia (...) and we tell you, friends, Danke schön.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened to this discussion with great interest. I want to thank you for your insights, for your comments and really again for your support. All of the EU, all the Member States continue to fight this crisis. We’re in the middle of this pandemic, and we need to fight it with all the means available to us. Yesterday, when we presented the European Health Union proposal, it is coming out from the lessons we have learnt, but are also learning, and what we need to do in order to respond to what citizens expect from us.  Many of you mentioned needing to do more about cancer, needing to do more about rare diseases. Yes, this is absolutely true, and in the EU4Health and with the increased budget that together we have achieved, we will be able to do a great deal more. We don’t have any time to lose. It is absolutely clear that we need to send these signals, and we owe it to our citizens in order to roll out what they have been demanding.  I want to end by saying that this House has played a key role by insisting on reinforcing the EU4Health budget significantly, and I really want to thank you for that, because coming from Parliament myself, I know I could not have done this, and we could not have done this as the Commission, without you. We can only do this together for one reason – because we share the same vision, a vision that is citizen-centred and health—centred. So I look forward to working with you on this important file, but let’s remember this is just the beginning. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.  The vote on the amendments will take place today and the final vote tomorrow, Friday 13 November 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Magdalena Adamowicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union's Health Action Programme 2021-2027, which is the subject of today's debate, responds to the calls of our citizens, who expect a much more active role for the European Union in the field of health. We should never again experience such drastic shortages of medical equipment as in recent months due to the coronavirus pandemic. No more healthcare professionals should find themselves in a situation where they have to choose which patients will receive life-saving equipment. The coronavirus pandemic must be a watershed moment for the European Union's health efforts. It is therefore an urgent priority today to create a European Health Union in which Member States can adequately prepare for and respond to possible health crises, acquire innovative medical products and jointly improve prevention, treatment and care for diseases such as cancer. The European Union has great potential to contribute to a better level of protection of the health of Europeans. I hope that the European Union for the Healthy will make the most of this potential.

name: Christine Anderson (ID)
text: Writing. – The Commission is taking an acceptable step in the right direction with the EU4Health programme, but there are no points in the areas of health care, so that medical treatment through an unhealthy lifestyle does not become necessary in the first place. Unfortunately, this is hardly or not talked about, let alone set as a goal. The causes of diseases must be combated instead of tinkering with the symptoms. I would like to give a few examples from the fields of sports promotion and schooling. By recognizing gyms as systemically important and enhancing the importance of school sports and avoiding corresponding downtime hours, especially against the background of the lack of exercise of the students, a significant increase in health in their lives can be achieved here not only for the students, but also for their future. In addition, more education in healthy and balanced nutrition can be done in schools and in the wider population. The aim must be to convince citizens of a healthy lifestyle as a child and to educate them accordingly about the consequences of an unhealthy diet. As a result, health in the general public can be gradually improved and the health system relieved.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We envision a strong health framework for the European Union. The ambitious, promising new Programme, EU4Health, should be left not only as a plan to tackle COVID19, but as a Master Plan that will address all health challenges. As the President of the Commission quite rightly noted, we are not going to stop anywhere in order to save lives. At the same time, we stress that we will not stop until the EU creates a strong health system framework that proactively saves the lives of European citizens, ensures high levels of health and extends to all levels, to all Member States and to every European citizen. A single health plan is needed, capable and effective to address all health risks, with an emphasis on Prevention. Planning for the management of health issues is not only about the current Koroniovirus Pandemic, but we care about all health challenges and problems such as the prevention and treatment of Cancer and other serious diseases. If we do not succeed in shielding the EU with a Strong and Unified Health System, then we will be weakened and fail to achieve a sovereign priority objective for all European citizens.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE)
text: Written. – Ladies and gentlemen, a stronger European Union in the field of health care is a real gamechanger. It is the first time in history that Europe has been so committed to health care. We must seize this moment and put the right emphasis on making the various health systems in the Member States resilient and forward-looking. For me, this text places crucial emphasis: more focus on prevention, promoting a healthy lifestyle and reducing social inequalities. I also support the demand for additional investment, health in all policies and an enhanced role for the European Medicines Agency and the European Agency for Disease Prevention and Control. The commitment to innovation and digitisation, combined with digital literacy in healthcare, is also becoming important. Moreover, as EPP Coordinator for the Special Committee on The Fight against Cancer, I am extremely pleased that the fight against cancer is explicitly being implemented and that the 'Europe's Beating Cancer Plan' is being implemented. Finally, there is also a strong emphasis on eliminating drug shortages, which will be a major challenge in the coming years. I am convinced that with the 5.1 billion, as provisionally agreed in the trilogies, we can make our health care stronger and more resilient. Ready for the future.

name: Joanna Kopcińska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 'Healthy citizens are the greatest asset of any country', which is why I support the dedicated Eu4Health health programme, whose current resources are still incomparably larger than the funding of existing programmes. The EU4Health programme is an ambitious, independent health initiative for the period 2021-2027 and I believe that fulfilling its objectives will make a significant contribution to improving the functioning of health systems after the COVID-19 pandemic. Through clearly defined objectives, I believe that the Programme will become a tool that broadly promotes health on the one hand and, on the other hand, will demonstrate areas for possible better cooperation and mitigation of inequalities in many areas of public health. In my work on the Programme, I focused in particular on actions in line with strategic priorities, i.e. digitising health care, eliminating the shortage of medicines - mentioning the restoration and maintenance of drug safety, and broad prevention measures to prevent chronic diseases, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. We have also not forgotten the provisions on better management of antimicrobials such as antibiotics. Complementarity and synergies (with the European Cancer Plan) and with other EU programmes will be based on respect for the division of competences in the field of health policy as set out in Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU (TFEU). I therefore look forward to very constructive interinstitutional negotiations with the Council and the Commission next week.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – With the recent provisional agreement between the European Parliament and the European Council, the budget of the EU Health Programme (EU4Health) has been increased to EUR 5.1 billion. With an initial budget of EUR 9.4 billion, this programme was practically sacrificed by the Council, which reduced the budget to just EUR 1.7 billion. The European Parliament has in no way accepted this setback, as the health of European citizens must remain our priority.  I continue to support the efforts of the European legislature to ensure a satisfactory budget that can support measures to reform and strengthen national health systems.  With the largest ever health budget, we will be able to flesh out measures to strengthen prevention, increase the resilience of health systems, reduce inequalities in access to health and digitise health.  My amendments aimed to improve equal access to health care, modern treatments, medicines and appliances, as well as to step up prevention action. We have contributed significantly to the better implementation of the programme by calling for annual programming and clear funding criteria.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – For the first time, the EU is laying the foundations for a European health programme. A set of actions to gather resources available at European level to generate solutions for all MS, reduce inequalities and increase the quality of the medical process. Since 2014, we have publicly called for the creation of such a programme. We need cooperation between MS, common solutions and to invest more, creating a Union of health. Our level of ambition needs to be higher. The EC proposed substantial allocation, but the Council reduced the amount. Investing in health must become a priority for the construction of a society in which European citizens have access to the best medical facilities. It is essential that these financial resources are invested in improving infrastructure, in training medical personnel, in order to increase the quality of the medical act, in research, but also in the creation of cooperation mechanisms, such as the creation of common medical units at European level for emergencies or in situations where Member States are experiencing difficulties. The proposal to create the Blue Medical Corps, built on a positive example given by Romanian doctors who went to Italy during the pandemic, can again show that together we are stronger.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. "I have long advocated closer EU health cooperation and pushed for an communicable diseases regulation that would set common criteria for the control, treatment and prevention of communicable diseases at EU level. It is important that we have common criteria at EU level for monitoring, preventing and regulating infectious diseases. The new regulation would be science-based and strengthen the resources and mandate of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). The regulation should also set a minimum level of investment in health in order to ensure that member states' health systems are well prepared for future pandemics. The EU4Health programme is a step in the right direction. It is important that the programme enables us to prepare more thoroughly for major cross-border health threats. Member States alone are not able to act effectively enough to protect citizens. Health is a global issue, and so should the solutions we are looking for. In addition, we must not turn a blind eye to future health threats, which must be proactively sought for solutions such as antibiotic resistance and the global health threats it causes.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Union action in the field of health is limited due to a lack of treaties, but the Union should pursue a coherent public health strategy to respond to existing epidemics, taking into account regional and national specificities. The Union should help Member States to reduce inequalities in the healthcare system and ensure universal health protection, address healthcare-related infections, and address vulnerable groups such as the European Commission. care for children, infants and mothers, an ageing population, chronic diseases and disease prevention and promoting a healthy lifestyle, providing prevention services and developing technologies for improving health systems. The experience gained during the COVID-19 crisis has demonstrated the need for further decisive action at Union level to support cooperation and coordination between Member States, in particular between neighbouring regions and also public authorities and relevant stakeholders. This cooperation should help to prepare for the spread, control, development and availability of products for the prevention and treatment of serious infectious human diseases across borders, and to combat other serious cross-border health threats. It would also help to protect and improve the health and well-being of all citizens of the Union. Let us not forget, however, that these decisions must be agreed with the Member States and must be presented only with their consent. Solidarity and unity are the principles of the Union and the health programme should ensure a coherent Approach by the Union to address cross-border health threats.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on transparency in the acquisition and access to COVID-19 vaccines (2020/2843(RSP)).

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I’m not going to repeat what I have already been saying, that we have been witnessing with great concern increasingly rapid infection rates and loss of life across the EU. Every day when we listen to the news and we hear in all our countries the number of people who have been admitted to hospitals to intensive care, the number of people who lose their lives, we understand that we need to do everything possible, and this is what we have been doing as a Commission from the very beginning. Vaccination is not going to be a magic solution that will allow us to go back to our everyday lives overnight. Unfortunately, for COVID—19 there is really no silver bullet and it is important that when we communicate to citizens, we are open and frank about this. But vaccinations, once we have a safe and effective vaccine, will play a crucial role. It will play a crucial role in saving lives, in containing the pandemic, in protecting our health systems and, of course, in restoring our economy. It will provide our citizens with a sense of hope and predictability. Predictability is something that we often take for granted, but what we have been living with in the last 10 months is the uncertainty of not knowing what the next day will hold. On Monday, we saw financial markets reacting with glee to the encouraging announcements from one of the vaccine developers. But I also saw something else, I saw the element of hope that European Union citizens felt with this news. We are therefore doing everything we can to ensure that vaccines are produced as quickly and as safely as possible. To maximise our chances of success, we have been working very intensively to have a diverse, common EU portfolio of vaccines against COVID—19 as soon as possible and developed using different technologies. The negotiations with companies have been intensive and inclusive, carried out with and for Member States. To date, we have signed three contracts, and are about to sign the fourth with Pfizer/BioNTech. Our negotiations are also advanced with another two companies and exploratory talks are ongoing with a number of producers. I have often been asked over the last few days, and I want to reassure you, that once a vaccine becomes available, all Member States will have equal access to the available doses at the same time, according to the agreements we have concluded. Now I fully recognise the importance of transparency in this process. Due to the highly competitive nature of this global market, the Commission is legally not able to disclose the information contained in the contracts. Non—disclosure clauses are a standard feature of these agreements that vaccine developers have also concluded with other countries. This is necessary to protect these sensitive negotiations and business—related information, such as financial information, development and production plans. The companies require that such sensitive business information remains confidential between the signatories of the contract. The Commission, therefore, cannot really decide to unilaterally disclose them without the consent of all involved parties. But these are rules that also protect the tendering process and we fully abide by them, not for the reasons linked to contractors’ commercial interests, but also because we do not want to weaken the position of the Commission in the negotiations. We need to be extremely careful during these negotiations, so that we do not have companies leading to cherry—picking on the best conditions. So let me conclude by addressing some of the worries that I’m sure I will hear about today and I have heard over the past weeks. Safety: safety is a fundamental requirement for any vaccine to be deployed in the EU. The safety of our citizens is a top priority and it is not negotiable for us. The European Medicines Agency will be doing everything possible once any vaccine submits for authorisation, to ensure that the safety dimension is covered. Let me stress this: we all need to have the same messaging because we see a lot of vaccination hesitancy. This has been ongoing before COVID—19 with vaccination hesitancy to do with children’s diseases, with measles, and we cannot afford to encourage this. So, what we want to do is have common communication and assure citizens that we will not lower the bar in terms of safety at any cost. Secondly, the agreements with the vaccine developers do not change or derogate from the EU legislation and rules on liability. Finally, we are acting in full compliance with all the applicable rules regarding financial management and are confident that the process will stand any future review or audit. I look forward to hearing this debate. I’m sure it is going to be a very lively one. I can assure you that over the last five to six months we have been working 24/7 on this and we need to continue to do this because it is possibly the only way we have out of this pandemic, but not at the cost of reducing safety concerns for citizens. I will never stop saying that. Thank you for your patience.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the This is a good week for the people of the European Union. The world's first serious vaccine has been developed in Europe and is produced in Europe, with funding from three different European Union funds. Of course, we have to look closely, and the EMA has yet to look at the results, but there is reason for hope. I know BioNTech and I think it is very serious. And we have a treaty. Europeans get the vaccine. Thanks to Stella Kyriakides, thanks to Sandra Gallina and also thanks to the President-in-Office of the Council, Jens Spahn, who has been very committed. I have three political messages today: the first to the right here in the House and elsewhere, which are always rushing against everything foreign. The founder of BioNTech came to Germany from Turkey at the age of four, and it is time to acknowledge the contribution of migrants to our society, to progress. Then there are the left and the Greens, who have always railed against these negotiations that the Commission is conducting. I speak in person: Michele Rivasi, Tilly Metz, Jutta Paulus. You have the opportunity today to apologise and say: hatoff, the Commission has done well. And thirdly, to all those who rail against the Corona protection measures: we have light at the end of the tunnel, and now it would be truly tragic if, as yesterday, almost 4 000 people continued to die from the virus. Let us stick together, let us keep our distance! Persevereing and following the rules is the order of the day – more than ever before.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, allow me to thank Stella Kyriakides for her work, your good work, Commissioner.  We are in the middle of the second wave of the COVID pandemic and the race for a safe and effective vaccine has never been more urgent. Researchers all around Europe – and the rest of the world – are working at an impressive speed to develop a safe and effective vaccine. Just the other day we received very promising results on a potential vaccine which is still undergoing clinical trials in testing phase 3. Although it is still too early to say for certain, the indicative results give some perspective for a return to life without fear of the virus. Even though I hear, Stella, what you say – we must still take care and we need to know that we still need the measures – but still this is promising.  Once again it shows the great potential of science. The Commission has signed three advance purchase agreements with different companies. We agree with the assessment that we need a broad portfolio with vaccine producers. It is crucial also to ensure that advance purchase agreements are fully transparent. We demand that the following provisions in the contract are made public: the cost for the producers of the vaccine and the prices to be paid; where the vaccine will be produced; the access to the vaccine; and also the liability linked to possible damage caused by the vaccine. This is absolutely fundamental.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the recent announcements on effective vaccines have high hopes, but we must remain cautious. Above all, we will have to make educational efforts. You see, Commissioner, there are currently two competing currents in my country, France, the country of Louis Pasteur, including within the same political party and among MEPs from the same party. These currents are both in error, because, as Talleyrand, another Frenchman, says, anything excessive is insignificant. The first stream wants to do coercion, rather than prevention, and proposes a vaccination obligation to the whole population. It is unrealistic and it is not the right way to do public health. We need to start with strategies to identify the populations that need to be protected as a priority. You are proposing a list of these priority individuals. Do you think it will be possible to be agreed between Member States to allow for a coordinated approach? The second, radically opposed trend, similar to the anti-vaccine lobby already cited by Peter Liese, systematically challenges scientific advances and takes advantage of the uncertain situation to cast doubt on the reliability of vaccines. It's dangerous and unreasonable. We have to react! How can we increase transparency on the terms of contracts with the pharmaceutical industry? Will information campaigns be considered to combat fake news and build trust? Commissioner, help us convince our citizens and our governments to build on the European Health Union, which you laid the foundation stone for yesterday. Citizens look at us and wait for us.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, many countries have already made commercial contracts for the pre-purchase of anti-COVID vaccines, in order to be reactive in the marketing of safe and effective vaccines. The European Union has done the same and pre-ordered, with public money already paid, 300 million doses from seven major laboratories. Negotiations are subject to presumptions of lack of clarity as to the negotiators, the terms of the contracts, the subject matter of the contract or any collateral effects. The negotiators: there are seven, all are not known, and at least one had high-level links with the pharmaceutical industry. Knowing a core business is one thing. Having conflicts of interest is another. The terms of the contracts. You have just said, Commissioner, that the negotiations must remain confidential. I will just remind you that you are our agent, to us European taxpayers. As a result, they are done at an accelerated pace and under the conditions of the pharmaceutical industry. There are compensation conditions for financial losses and, above all, an exemption from laboratory liability for vaccine side effects. And the Commission itself refuses to accept any health responsibility, at the risk of blocking maximum acceptance. The purpose of the contract is itself tainted with opacity. Despite recent announcements of available vaccine, no one knows when, how or where vaccination campaigns will be able to take place. Finally, the collateral effects. By definition, they are now unpredictable. Already, the whole field of pharmacy - and thanks to public money, let's remember it once again - is the subject of unprecedented stock market speculation. Above all, the fair and necessary respect for intellectual property on patents should not lead to unaffordable prices and prevent poor countries from accessing the vaccine. That would prolong the epidemic. HIV was only really held back when the whole world, or almost, had access to ART.

name: Tilly Metz
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, as you know, there is a great deal of expectation, and also of fear, on the part of citizens about the future vaccine against COVID-19, and it is our role as European representatives to reassure them. But how do you expect us to do that if you do not give us the information you need to do that? It is the principle of good cooperation between the Commission and Parliament that is at stake, and our right to information is being violated. I therefore call on you to address this as soon as possible and to make public the contracts with the industry, as well as to do your best to publish the clinical trial data before future vaccines are put on the market. This is essential to ensure citizens' confidence in the Union's actions and in this future vaccine. We must be exemplary in the management of this crisis and the duty of transparency is one of them.

name: Helmut Geuking
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The time has come, we will have a vaccine. After that it looks like. In the spring, the vaccinations are likely to be allowed to begin, optimistically. But vaccinations alone are not enough. We must not forget that. Because we need effective therapies, effective medicines. Vaccination itself reflects a deceptive safety. Many citizens will not be vaccinated. You were right to recognise this, Commissioner, because there are people here who are going to break the whole thing, say badly, whatever. This is where awareness-raising campaigns are needed and so on. We need to regulate and discuss urgent matters, such as patent protection. Is public services of general interest available worldwide? Because we have poured the money into research. Do we not now also have the right to have the appropriate patent protection? Because we need production facilities, even in the poorer countries. We need short distances, that is, to distribute production sites around the world that produce vaccines. And the medication: we have to debate and advise on a lot of things here. We must advise on the ethical, legal and medical requirements of vaccination. Which citizen? Where do we start? Do we take the WHO recommendation? And, and, and. But that requires a parliament capable of acting. And now I am making it very brief: I call on the President to restore the capacity of this Parliament to act. The daily allowances, the travel allowances, so that Members can come here and debate in a vibrant democracy. And I always make suggestions, we have made proposals, for example there are air purification filters, there are rapid tests. We have submitted it in writing, no answers. I am also waiting for the legal basis for the deletion. We need a Parliament that works in these times and not a President of Parliament who prevents the work. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marc Botenga
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, you have signed very large contracts with the pharmaceutical industry, and when European citizens ask you to see these contracts, you say that they can look elsewhere, that you are not accountable. That seems to me to be wrong. So I did a little survey myself. I was looking at it first, and I saw that multinational pharmaceutical companies sell their products very expensively and that you, in fact, say that you negotiate but you pay exactly the price they charge. Gilead's asking you for $1 billion, you're giving you $1 billion. Pfizer is asking you for $5 billion, you're giving you $5 billion. That is not negotiating, it is bowing down. Second, I also saw that you do not know exactly what you are buying. Because we had a press release from Pfizer on this vaccine, Pfizer says "our vaccine is 90% effective." All right, it gives hope, the stock market explodes. While the CEO of Pfizer sells his shares, you buy 300 million doses. But we don't know what this "efficiency" means. Does this mean that you are protected from mild symptoms but also from serious illness? It is not said. Does that mean that it is only the young people who are protected and not the elderly? All of these are questions that we want answers to. And finally, with all this money spent, we don't know if there will be a vaccine for everyone. There will be people who may not have access to this vaccine. So sincerely, I think it's time to start being accountable to citizens, stop protecting Big Pharma and please publish these contracts now.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, this week we witnessed the potentially historic news that the COVID-19 vaccine is almost ready. On Wednesday, the Commission received another contract to purchase up to 300 million doses of coronavirus vaccine that will be available to all Member States and, in particular, at the outset, to those at-risk groups that we need to protect the most. On the other hand, let's remind ourselves, the World Health Organization has declared opposition to vaccination one of the ten threats to global health in 2019. Opposition to vaccination refers to the late acceptance or refusal of vaccines despite the availability of vaccination services. The question of the importance of vaccination should not be in dispute in the 21st century. But certain groups and politicians make it complex and questionable, using incomplete, false and even dangerous information. Such opposition to vaccination is a challenge we need to focus on.  Through these treaties, Europe has provided its citizens with a wide range of vaccine candidates, most of whom are in advanced trials. As for the transparency of the procurement of future vaccines, I must point out that we all want a quick and secure solution that is also transparent. The negotiations and treaties concluded by the Commission are fully compliant and are an excellent example of caring for their own populations. The right balance has been struck between protecting the health of the population on the one hand and speed, transparency and accountability.  I'm sorry that some politicians are against this kind of practice just to make cheap political points for themselves, but I'm glad to see that they failed to do so, nor will they succeed. Europe is united and will remain united.

name: Sara Cerdas (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the ippinence of having a vaccine available brings great challenges for everyone. From the perspective of an early resolution of this pandemic, there is hesitation in vaccinating.  Here it is important to be realistic and realize that, very difficult, everything will return to what it was before, despite the importance of a safe and effective vaccine.  The Union has done well and today the added value of joint acquisitions is undeniable. They ensure that we are at the forefront of ensuring fair access for European citizens to a vaccine.  But for that and despite the positive news of recent days, there is still a long way to go. And full transparency throughout this process is essential. Only then can we ensure citizens' confidence in this massive immunisation that is intended to be swift.  It is important to know here the state of the state of the pharmacovigilance monitoring studies carried out by the European Medicines Agency and the European Centre for Disease Control and Prevention. Will this process condition the availability of the vaccine within the European Union?  What are the actions that are contemplated for the development of possible adverse effects, not in the short, medium and long term, for the need for a suspension of the distribution of the vaccine?  We have a duty to inform and European citizens have the right to be informed. Let us have this premise as an objective.

name: Pascal Canfin (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, two weeks ago, as chairman of the Environment and Public Health Committee, I sent you a letter asking for transparency on key elements of the contracts you are signing. Our requests are justified and balanced requests, we do not ask you for full transparency of contracts. What for? Because we know that in these contracts, there are indeed clauses that are a matter of professional secrecy, of industrial secrecy. However, there is no reason why you should not be able to publish the price of vaccines, the margin made by the laboratories. What is the cost structure, how do you control this cost structure, what is the legal liability regime, what is intellectual property? We put a lot of money in, do we cede all the intellectual property to private companies, or not? And finally, the place of production. These are four elements that should not remain opaque. You are draping yourself behind legal arguments that will not hold up, and behind it, politically, we want this vaccine to succeed. Make no mistake, Commissioner, we all want this vaccine to succeed. But for it to succeed, it must be widely accepted. And for it to be widely accepted, there must be trust. And for there to be trust, there must be transparency, especially on these four key elements. Please help us convince people that they can then trust it, it is a major public health issue. Let us not make the industrial error of tests and masks again, let us succeed in the battle of vaccines.

name: Simona Baldassarre (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is currently devastated by the pandemic. To date, there are over 13 million positive tampons, although we do not know how many are unique subjects, how many asymptomatics, how many serious cases, the time of stay and rotation in intensive care and, above all, the number of subjects who have developed immunity. Unfortunately, families and all citizens have been asked to make enormous emotional, psychological and economic sacrifices, in ways that are often questionable, given the results. We regret that this European Union has not been up to the task. The warnings of the threat were there from the outset: I myself spoke in this House in January to denounce the fact that the European Union was underestimating border controls, with ineffective and belated actions. Almost two months late! The ECDC has also only set in motion a pandemic that has now begun and the 2005 European pandemic plan has never been updated or put into practice, national pandemic plans have been denied, secreted and published only in part. And the Commission has answered our questions vaguely. Now we can't fail on vaccines yet. We call for maximum transparency, at all stages that will lead to an effective vaccine: transparency on who produces it, on its interests and on the effects on people's health. We ask how the EUR 660 million that the Commission has earmarked for the development of vaccines, new treatments, diagnostic tests and medical systems has been spent. We are asking for clarity on the early purchase agreements, which Mrs von der Leyen is concluding – the last with Pfizer for 300 million doses. We are calling for transparency in distribution, with the guarantee that there will be no second-class and second-class citizens, all the more so since there is no mapping of the immune population. The news of the imminent arrival of more vaccines is comforting. In the hope that they will be safe and effective, politics must now play its part. Let us avoid mistakes and guarantee freedom and security for all European citizens.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are still in an incredible situation. We are experiencing a global health crisis, we see that there are now more than 200 laboratories trying to find a vaccine, and there are 7 to 8 that are in phase III.  So we hope to really find a safe and effective vaccine. But in the vaccines that are offered to us, some are still special. Either we have genetically modified vaccines, in the case of AstraZeneca, for example, or we have messenger RNA vaccines and these vaccines have never been allowed at the human level at this time.  To regain trust - everyone is talking about the trust of European citizens - well, we need full transparency. I agree with others that, for there to be social acceptability for vaccination, for people to have confidence in vaccines, what do we need? We need the transparency of contracts, we need to know how much Europe has given to the laboratories, we need to know the cost of vaccines, we must also know the intellectual property that you give to laboratories that are going to make money too. So trust is built.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for being here with us. The expectation regarding the vaccine is legitimate. We are living one of the biggest public health crises and challenges we have ever known. But we need to know exactly what was negotiated. The issue of transparency is not a matter of any importance. The Commissioner said that all Member States will have access to vaccines according to what has been negotiated. Can citizens know or not know what was negotiated? Can citizens know or not know who will have access? These issues are fundamental for us to have an answer to the crisis we are experiencing. Besides, we also need respect. The European Union and european citizens have paid millions of euros to pharmaceutical companies to develop this vaccine and, at the hearings we are doing at the level of the parliamentary committee, there are pharmaceutical industries that do not even respect appearing and accountability. We also need to know who the property of knowledge will be. Again, are we talking about public money and private knowledge? It will not be the case if we discuss who this property is and say: it is a very important public investment and, therefore, it can not be business.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, Dia dhaoibh ar maidin, a chairde, ó oifig Pharlaimint na hEorpa i mBaile Átha Cliath. To paraphrase the great Irish poet, William Butler Yeats, ‘all’s changed, changed utterly: a terrible virus is born’. Yet the announcement of a more than 90% effective COVID—19 vaccine is very encouraging news and offers a glimmer of hope that we may reclaim normal lives from the hands of this terrible virus. This vaccine, produced by BioNTech in collaboration with Pfizer, which has a base in Cork in my own constituency, has been described as a huge success for European research and innovation policy, and rightly so. Partly financed by Horizon 2020, InnovFin and the European Fund for Strategic Investments, this is really a positive achievement for European research. There’s no harm in informing people about this, and perhaps we should send an email to the likes of Boris Johnson, Donald Trump and Marine Le Pen. I’m sure they’d be delighted.  However, a good vaccine must be efficient, safe, affordable, developed quickly and be able to achieve EU market authorisation. I therefore welcome the news that the European Commission have completed a deal to purchase up to 300 million doses of this frontrunner vaccine. Of course, we need buy—in from citizens, and that requires both trust and transparency. We must continue to work to ensure the widespread availability of vaccines because everybody must have access to it. We will not be safe until everybody is safe. So our task is clear – provide a vaccine that is universally available, easily accessible, affordable and effective and brings trust. We need trust for it to be effective.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, now that we are hopeful of progress in obtaining a safe and effective vaccine for the COVID-19 pandemic, it is a good time to remember the criteria that should guide this process: scientific guarantees and safety for our citizens; accessibility of the future vaccine but, at the same time, prioritizing risk groups; and obviously we want a vaccine that is affordable in terms of price for states but free for our citizens.  At the same time I want to send two messages. One: Europe is giving us bargaining power over pharmaceutical companies in procurement processes, with four contracts already signed, but that bargaining power cannot be detrimental to transparency, necessary transparency to protect the general interest, obviously, and build trust in our citizens. And, at the same time, it should be remembered that this whole process is being made possible by public-private collaboration, because all public administrations, states, European institutions are turning large amounts of public money to find the vaccine.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President! Everyone longs to be allowed to live an ordinary life in our community again, and apparently everyone here also longs to know what is actually going on. The EU has so far spent more than DKK 20 billion on negotiations with industry to provide member states with vaccines, but the public still knows too little. Many questions remain unanswered: what do the contacts look like? How much has gone into expanding production and how does this support reflect in the final price of the vaccine? Will independent researchers have full access to the clinical trials results before the vaccine is offered to citizens? And what about liability in case of side effects? Is the industry hanging on to it or the state, that is, the citizens themselves? At a minimum, we must be guaranteed transparency about everything within one year of the product being put on the market, so that both industry and the European Commission are aware that they will be held accountable, even if we know in advance that there is almost no effect. We're not going to have another Tamiflu scandal.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Occasionally I am asked what the European Union is actually doing to combat the pandemic. I can say with great passion that we are doing a lot, and we are also doing a lot of good things, as we have just seen again in the last few days. Firstly, we, as Europeans, have secured the vaccine. I would like to thank the Commission very, very much today. I think you have done a great job, Commissioner. Less than 24 hours after announcing the breakthrough in the vaccine, the Commission has already reserved hundreds of millions of doses of vaccine for European citizens. It's really a really, really great achievement. I would like to thank you very, very much for that. I am also confident that the distribution of the vaccine among the 27 Member States will be fair. Thank you for your suggestions. As Europeans, of course, when we place orders for 440 million citizens, we are throwing a very different weight at the scales, and I am pleased that we have not been able to fight among the 27 states here over who can get the vaccine first. If it had been for the Greens and the Left – and I would also like to stress this, especially if I were following the debate today – we would still have no treaty, no option for a single dose of vaccination. Secondly, as Europeans, we have supported BioNTech, the company that made the breakthrough, with many European funds. I say that our research and innovation policy is also in the right position. A thank you for that, too. Let us be a little proud today that we Europeans are doing something good for ourselves. It really is a good day for us in Europe.

name: Romana Jerković (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioners, we are again facing a record number of infected. Some Member States have entered a new lockdown. Our health systems have once again been brought to the brink of sustainability. Medical staff are making superhuman efforts to provide care to anyone in need, while the economy continues to falter or stagnate at best.  Insofar as this week's announcement on progress made in developing a new vaccine certainly instills a whiff of optimism. But there's no room for euphoria. The situation remains very critical and requires additional engagement from all of us. When we talk about the availability of vaccines in the coming period, three things will be crucial. First, ensure the safety and effectiveness of vaccines and we must not compromise there. Second, strengthen production capacity to meet high demand and thirdly, develop plans and global distributions.  At all stages, I agree with my predecessors, transparency is extremely important. Our fellow citizens have sent us a clear message that they want more Europe in their everyday life, and I therefore want to express my satisfaction that yesterday the European Commission published a communication on building a European Health Union, as this is a very important step in strengthening our collective readiness for future health threats.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I think we are all very happy that there are these positive signals today. And it is all the more important that we now also pursue a common, coordinated strategy when it comes to fair distribution. The ECDC has already made very good proposals on this. After all, in addition to the employees in health professions or the particularly exposed groups, it must be above all about protecting the weak, the vulnerable in our society. These are people with pre-existing conditions, these are people with health problems, such as many physically disabled people, but they are also people in difficult housing conditions. I hope that the European Union will find a good common approach to this.
