However, I have to say something, dear Mr Liese: we have always said as Greens – I do not know, I did not follow that – : happy to have treaties, but they must be transparent. It must be clear what the billions of European taxpayers are being spent on. I am very pleased that Mrs Guteland and Mr Canfin and many others have also raised this issue. We weren't concerned with anything else. We need transparency, because that is the only way to build trust.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I want to thank the House for your words of encouragement at these times and for supporting our vaccine strategy, but I really feel that credit needs also to go to my whole team in my Cabinet, my DG, and especially Director Sandra Gallina, for all the negotiations – this needs to be said.  Now until we have found a sustainable solution, we have all agreed at least that the coronavirus affects each and every day of our lives. And until we have found a sustainable solution it will continue to impact on our societies, on our economies and on the everyday way we live. So a safe, effective and affordable vaccine, universally accessible, is a crucial exit to the pandemic. I also believe that we share the vision that we want what is best for our citizens. We want them to have the vaccine as soon as possible and under the best possible conditions.  Now to do so – and I want to be clear because I have heard questions on the negotiations from several Members and I need to answer them. First of all, Member States had to organise with the Commission a new process. We presented a vaccine strategy a few months ago. I want to assure you that we’re following both EU law and the vaccine strategy, and Member States have been part of this constant negotiation process so that we would be as inclusive as possible from the very beginning.  It is important that we all understand that this way of working, with and for 27 Member States, fully guarantees both accountability and compliance with the rules that protect the interests of those involved, but in doing so we must also respect the rules on what information can be made public and what has to remain protected. And more crucially, we need to work together to deliver a lasting and decisive solution for our citizens.  There were questions on liability. I will repeat what I said in my opening remarks: that the agreements with the vaccine developers do not change or derogate from EU legislation and rules on liability.  There were questions on when a vaccine will be available, how will citizens know about this. Well first of all, let us be clear, we are still not at the point when any company has submitted for market authorisation to the European Medicines Agency. You have seen with us that along the phase of clinical trials you can have twists and turns. So I think we have to be cautious about saying when a vaccine will be available and when it would reach citizens. We have spoken of best case scenarios for the end of this year or the beginning of the next, but again I follow what Véronique Trillet-Lenoir also said: that we have to be very cautious in our communication with citizens. Véronique Trillet-Lenoir also spoke about the need for prioritisation, which citizens will be vaccinated first, and I wanted to share with you that we have been working on this with the ECDC (European Centre for Disease Prevention) and we’ve already shared with Member States which groups, what prioritisation they should look at. But of course all Member States will be doing this according to their own situation on the ground.  In terms of rapid tests, which were mentioned, and antigen tests, we have been looking at this with the ECDC for the last few weeks and we hope to come out with guidance next week for the settings of rapid tests. On tests of therapeutics – this was also mentioned and you’re absolutely right – we haven’t taken our eyes off therapeutics for the last eight months. I have had weekly calls with the European Medicines Agency and with the ECDC every day for over eight months now and we follow every single development as it comes out on therapeutics.  In terms of efficacy: until we have a safe and effective vaccine that has actually been submitted for authorisation and we have the independent scientific assessment by the European Medicines Agency, I think it is too early to start now hypothesising whether this vaccine will be used for the young, the old, for prevention. We will know that once we have a safe and effective vaccine.  But what I can assure you of is that we are leaving no stone unturned in order to be able to ensure that we have a result as quickly as possible. And because speed often creates concern, why so quickly? Well, we are in a time when the whole world is investing in this research but also there are now different technologies which allow us to move much more quickly for this. I heard from the Chair of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), Pascal Canfin, about the importance of trust. He’s absolutely correct in this, and it’s important that we know that transparency creates trust and trust is key. We’ve heard your concerns about transparency and what I can tell you is that within the contractual constraints, we are ready to explore making information about the contracts available to nominated Members of the Parliament, with specific arrangements, once the sensitive ongoing negotiations are concluded.  So let us move forwards together. We need your support in the roll-out of vaccines in your Member States and in building trust in the solution that citizens expect from us.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. " It has been a difficult and unprecedented year around the world. The COVID pandemic has touched hard without exception all. For the first time in such a long period of time, we live in isolation and we must come to terms with the necessary restrictions in order to curb this pandemic. Kap has repeatedly mentioned today that it is very important that restrictions imposed by Member States are very important . However, the powers relating to the state of emergency must be subject to additional scrutiny in order to ensure that they are not used as a pretext for a long-term change in the balance of powers , and that this does not undermine the rights of our citizens or otherwise unduly restrict their freedoms and rights, nor is it necessary to rein in the pandemic . We expect better EU-wide coordination from the Commission in order to ensure equal treatment with regard to restrictions and, in particular, for intra-EU travel. The different measures and requirements applied by the Member States make the already extremely difficult situation even more difficult, and we would like a single approach at EU level. I would like to congratulate the Commission on its efforts in organising the purchase of vaccines at EU level . Only in this way will we be able to ensure access to vaccines for all EU citizens . Solidarity between the Union is more necessary than ever, and I very much hope that we will finally overcome this crisis through joint efforts.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The second wave of the coronavirus epidemic has hit the European Union with great force. The spread of the virus can be slowed by the cooperation and sacrifice of European citizens and by appropriate measures taken by national governments. However, only the development of a reliable, safe and effective vaccine can be a definitive solution. Positive news about the testing of coronavirus vaccines may give rise to cautious optimism. It is particularly gratifying that among the projects of hope are vaccines co-financed by the Member States and the European Union. Safe vaccination can bring predictability and stability back to their daily lives as soon as possible for europeans. It is important that vaccines are acquired and made available in accordance with the relevant legislation and with sufficient scientific thoroughness. However, in order to act swiftly and effectively, confidence must be given to EU and Member State authorities. We cannot allow the ideological slogans voiced by the European left to de-vaccinate against the epidemic. Finally, when it comes to the control of the coronavirus, it is also worth taking into account good practices in the Member States. Such a good example is Hungary which initiated the establishment of the National Vaccine Factory in order to ensure universal access to the vaccine.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D)
text: Writing. – It is good that, following the longer-lasting and initially low-effective response of central European authorities to the COVID-19 outbreak, the European Commission continues to take steps to better manage this health crisis in all EU countries. The European Commission has signed pre-contract agreements with a number of pharmaceutical suppliers, which should ensure that a diversified vaccine portfolio is created for our citizens as much as possible. It is now important to ensure that citizens receive only vaccines that definitively demonstrate not only high efficacy, but also maximum safety. However, I must stress that the whole process of procuring vaccines is not transparent enough for us MEPs either. I understand that not everything is possible because of trade secrets, but the Commission still needs to significantly improve communication on this whole process. It is important for all of us, including in Slovakia, that the European Commission commits itself to ensuring a vaccine for all those who need it, and that it is still this winter. It is not up to the central authorities, but the Member States, what categories of population they include in the first set of vaccinations. Vaccination should not be compulsory, but the European Commission, together with the governments of the Member States, should ensure the highest quality and most trusted information on the benefits of vaccination.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: in writing. – Mister President, Madame Commissioner, the whole Europe, the whole world, is impatiently waiting for a vaccine against COVID-19. We have heard some promising news lately about advanced stages of clinical trials in the search of such a vaccine and that gives hope. And while researchers and scientists are doing their part, we, as policy makers, must do ours and that means that we have to make sure that the vaccine, once ready, is available to all. Appropriate mechanisms and procedures have to be put in place to provide for a swift roll-out of the vaccination process. That means that already now the EU and the Member States need to be preparing scenarios for effective distribution chains. Every day of delay would mean further lost lives. I would like to underline one more important element of the vaccination process - trust of citizens as to the safety and value of it. We have been witnessing a disturbing spread of anti-vaccine misinformation fuelled by supporters of conspiracy theories. Misinformation in the area of public health can have literally deadly effects so we have to fight it very hard.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR)
text: in writing. – No European country may go free to purchase COVID-19 vaccines that are being developed by many pharmaceutical companies. Member States will have to bend to what the European Commission decides and will not be able to negotiate their acquisition separately. Why has the shopping centre been established in Brussels? This practice could break healthy competition. Will there be a diversified portfolio of vaccines to deal with coronavirus?  Accelerating the development, production and deployment of COVID-19 vaccines can compromise safety. We hope that the European Commission will not promote the use of any vaccine before all clinical trials are successfully completed and proven to be effective both in avoiding and transmitting the disease. We need a vaccine to trust that can be one of the tools to help us contain the pandemic.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE)
text: Writing. – In 2020, the coronavirus epidemic has created an exceptional situation throughout Europe, the number of diseases is increasing and in the midst of the second wave we can say that the virus will only end if there is a vaccine. The vaccine strategy was adopted in June this year with the main aim of providing high-quality, safe, effective and affordable vaccines to all citizens. Under the Strategy, the European Commission has already concluded five contracts with various pharmaceutical companies, greatly increasing the chances that a sufficient number of vaccines will be available at the end of the year and next year and that the control of the coronavirus epidemic will be successful. I welcome the European Commission's efforts to obtain vaccines, and I am also shocked to see that there are those who are looking for a knot in this extraordinary situation. The European Commission is a regular guest at meetings of the ENVI Committee and has responded to comments and questions on transparency on numerous occasions, stressing that it is 'legally incapable of publishing the information contained in the treaties'. Dear Colleagues, Saving lives is now the main goal, please be responsible and work together to ensure that everyone has access to the vaccine as soon as possible and in an equal way.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Siegfried Murean and Paul Tang on behalf of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the subject of 'Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe - Financing the Green Deal' (2020/2058(INI)) (A9-0198/2020).

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to welcome Vice—President Dombrovskis back to the European Parliament. Paul Tang and myself, as co-rapporteurs, are presenting to you today Parliament’s report on the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan. This is the financing of the Green Deal: it’s an own-initiative report by Parliament which should lay the framework for the financing of the Green Deal, because we believe much of the success of the Green Deal will depend on its financing. We have set ambitious objectives there, and we will only meet those objectives if we follow suit with appropriate financial resources. Resources will be needed from the European level, from the national level and from the local level, and they will be needed from the private and from the public sector alike in order to meet these objectives. We started our work on this report immediately after the Commission presented the Green Deal and the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan – that was at the beginning of this year. It was before the start of the pandemic, and we set ambitious objectives. The one thing which I want to say very clearly for Parliament now is that we are sticking to the objectives of the Green Deal: combating climate change; polluting less; improving our energy efficiency. Those need to be permanent tasks. They should not only be tasks that we are busy with when there is no other crisis. So we are committed to the objectives of the Green Deal, but obviously we need to see, together with the Commission, how we ensure the financing in the new context. We set the objective to mobilise EUR 1 trillion for the next 10 years before the pandemic, but we are seeing that the pandemic is affecting our economies, and it is affecting our enterprises, and we need to reach the objectives of the Green Deal together with our enterprises and with our economies, not against them. The first important question will be, how much financing can we mobilise and how much can the private sector do to reach these objectives? This is why the report which Paul Tang and myself are putting in front of you today raises an important element. Will we reach, Vice-President Dombrovskis, the leverage effects that we were planning at the beginning of the year? We need to see if the objectives which we had for the next 10 years are reachable, and how. We need to see if the leverage effects which we were planning at the beginning of the year are realistic and we also need to see what the synergies between the resources that we mobilised after the pandemic and the objectives of the Green Deal will be. How will Next Generation EU, the recovery and resilience facility, contribute to these objectives? We, as the European Parliament, are setting ambitious green objectives, including for the recovery and resilience facility. The Commission rightly proposed 37% climate mainstreaming under the recovery and resilience facility. We, as the European Parliament, are backing the Commission in the 37%, but I am going one small step further and I am proposing 40%. The question is, do we count the resources from the recovery resilience facility under the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan or not? This is an important question that we need to clarify together. We also recognise the important role of the EU budget and the positive contribution towards reaching the objectives of the Green Deal which cohesion policy has, which research policy has, which agriculture policies have and which the Just Transition Fund also has.  With regard to the Just Transition Fund, I would like to say that it is crucial that the Just Transition Fund is sufficiently financed and that the climate transition takes into consideration the different levels of development and dependence on fossil fuels in different EU Member States. Obviously Member States are deciding by themselves their own energy mixes. We are committed and Member States are committed – they should be committed – to transitioning from the least clean sources of energy, but we need to see how the transition can take place from country to country. We, in our report, are also saying that the projects with the highest potential to reach our climate objectives should be financed as a priority and we also say that a level playing field should be guaranteed for EU companies. We are also aware of the importance of own resources, where the Council, the Commission and Parliament have made together very good progress for a calendar for own resources in the next seven years. We see own resources as a source of revenue, but also as a tool to incentivise greening at the level of consumers and at the level of the private sector. We believe that private financing is very important as well because, as I said, financial needs are very big. The investment needs are between EUR 250 and 400 billion per year. We, as the public sector, are doing our part, but we need a commitment from the private sector as well. And the role of the European Investment Bank is also important, as well as other financial institutions, such as such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. This being said, Madam President, I would like to thank my co-rapporteur Paul Tang for the excellent work which we did together, himself on behalf of the Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) Committee, myself on behalf of the Budget Committee, and all of our shadow rapporteurs, who really spent tens of hours in the negotiations with us.  The report was adopted with a very large majority at the level of the committees. We’re looking forward to the final vote tomorrow in plenary, and then we’re looking forward to the cooperation with the European Commission on the basis of what Parliament will be saying in this report.

name: Paul Tang
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, let me remind you that one month ago this House took a giant step towards securing the future of our planet. The European Parliament pledged to commit Europe to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 60% and set in this way an example for the rest of the world. It was sometimes seen as impossible, and also in this House, but don’t call something impossible if you haven’t looked for the possibilities and this report – and I present together with Siegfried Mureşan – is about making possible. Yes, much money is needed. I recently saw a calculation that economists say that we need an additional EUR 300 billion each year to reach the goals of the Paris Agreement. At the same time, that’s only 3% of the amount of money that we are spending now on COVID support by national governments. So let’s be honest, it can be done.  Indeed, what this report does is build a bridge between ambition and reality. Our bridge has four arches and we need all of them to reach our aims. The four arches are the EU budget, the EU’s monetary and financial institutions, private investment and public spending. Let me start with the EU budget. Siegfried Mureşan has already addressed part of it, including own resources, but let me add two things. First, don’t allow green washing. With the EU taxonomy, we obliged the financial sector to back any claims of sustainability. But what kind of government applies a set of rules to others and not to itself? That’s why we clearly state EU spending on sustainability must be taxonomy compliant. Second, don’t shoot yourself in the foot. How can we spend money on fighting climate change if we subsidise fossil fuels at the same time? How can we spend money on social services if public money supports a company that dodges taxes and exploits employees. That is why all EU spending, including the Next Generation EU, including through the EIB, should adhere to the important principle of do no significant harm. Environmental and social progress need to go hand—in—hand.  Next up are the EU’s monetary and financial institutions. The EIB and the ECB have billions to spend. Let’s make sure that they spend it wisely – again, in line with the EU taxonomy and without harming people or the planet – to reach our aims of the Paris Agreement. In doing so, no stone should be left unturned. New Green Bonds should be issued by the EIB, whereas the ECB needs to reform its corporate sector purchasing programme. As supervisor, the ECB needs to force banks to address climate—related risks that are still on the balance sheets of banks.  The third arch concerns private investment. The report insists on the phasing—out of all investment in harmful activities. Soon investment in new fossil fuel plants and unsustainable heavy industry will be history. The market is already moving in that direction, but sometimes a lack reliable data can hamper progress. We need good and publicly accessible data and for credit rating agencies to take these data into account.  The last part of the bridge between ambition and reality is public spending. The national governments make the bulk of public spending and investments. The EU should stimulate them to do it sustainably, not hamper them. Therefore, we call for new tools, such as a Green Bond standard, to make this easy. But governments also need revenue. Tax avoidance cuts the ground under governments’ feet. We need to fight tax avoidance as concerns corporate profits and private wealth. Other incomes should come from taxing polluters – the polluter pays principle. Indeed, the Energy Tax Directive is out of date. The excise duties have lost their effect due to inflation and they should be corrected. Let’s face it, kerosene should eventually be taxed in line with other fossil fuels. With this report, the European Parliament shows how it bridges the gap between ambition and reality, bringing a sustainable society closer and closer.  My last remark is to thank Siegfried Mureşan, my co—rapporteur, for very close and fine cooperation. It is much appreciated. I would also like to thank very much the shadows because we have worked in difficult circumstances and we required a lot of your patience and efforts. You have always been very constructive, which Siegfried and I appreciate very much.

name: Πέτρος Κόκκαλης
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, climate neutrality requires innovation at all levels and not just in technology. The climate law we recently passed is an example of regulatory and political innovation. Innovation, plan and firm will are essential for the green transition and the financial sector. With the Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe and, above all, in view of the forthcoming revision of the Sustainable Finance Strategy, we are putting the foundations for the success of the European Green Agreement and the building of a socially, economically and ecologically resilient Europe. In view of the implementation of the agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework reached yesterday, we must ensure that public money produces public goods and that it promotes and does not undermine public health, social cohesion and climate security. It is time to integrate these objectives into the core of the financial sector. But taxonomics, the 'no harm' principle and the framework for green bonds are the tools that should guide not only private but also public investment. Above all, the European Semester must be reformed to focus on the well-being of people, not numbers.  Ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to support the amendments tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety which help a good text to move in an even better direction. Ladies and gentlemen, time is not on our side and we must ensure that, from now on, every euro is a 'green' euro and that no euro is a 'black' euro. Thank you very much, thank you colleagues for your cooperation.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Mureşan and Mr Tang, for their report. Nearly ten months ago, the Commission adopted the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan, which is an investment plan for the European Green Deal. On that day I presented the plan to this Parliament. As I speak to you today, I’m struck by how much the world has changed since then. The EU fight against climate change and environmental degradation now takes place amid an unprecedented health and economic crisis of COVID—19. The EU has taken immediate action to fight the pandemic, and we are sparing no effort to support the economy. But as your report also highlights, the climate change crisis has not disappeared. Today, I assure you that the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan is as relevant as it was in January. In fact, it’s even more critical now as we support the economic recovery. Our commitment to become the first climate—neutral continent by 2050 remains firm, and we have proposed more ambitious emissions cuts by 2030. We will need massive investment to reach those goals. Through the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan, the EU set out how to generate at least one trillion euros of sustainable investments over the next decade. The Commission welcomes the historic agreement between the European Parliament and the Council on the EU’s next long—term budget and Next Generation EU. It will also be fundamental for the green recovery, but public finance will not be enough. Investor appetite for sustainable opportunities is on the rise. We will harness this demand by enabling frameworks, for example the EU taxonomy and EU Green Bond Standard. I’m happy that European financial institutions are also stepping up to the mark. Both the European Investment Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development are increasing their ambitions in green finance and both are looking into using the EU taxonomy in their activities. International cooperation beyond EU borders is also needed to scale up sustainable finance. The EU’s key role in the International Platform for Sustainable Finance is at the heart of this global response. Honourable Members, our massive recovery package is fully in line with the Green Deal. The Commission also agrees with the Parliament that leaving no one behind is now more important than ever. We look forward to working with the European Parliament in translating these ambitions into relevant sectoral legislations. Your efforts will be an important reference point as we push ahead with our plan to finance the Green Deal in a sustainable and fair manner.

name: Caroline Nagtegaal
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Madam President, the COVID-19 crisis we’re facing today has shown that the transport and logistics sector, as well as its workers, has proven to be the backbone of the ‘cure and stay-at-home’ economy. The uninterrupted freight transport of medical equipment and food has been essential for its functioning and the continued operation of supply chains during the pandemic. As rapporteur on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), I stressed in our opinion that transport and tourism should be given an important role in the financing plans surrounding the Green Deal. So in that regard, I’m very glad to see that the report prepared by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Committee on Budgets (BUDG) mentioned the important role of SMEs in the transport and also the tourism sector, and the call to revise the EIB transport lending policy in order to open financial opportunities for sustainable and digital innovations. But to be honest, we have to do more. Substantial support and close public—private cooperation is needed for the completion of the trans-European transport network. And on top of this, the sector needs support in a transition in order to comply with the goals of the Green Deal. And then you have to think of boosting the use of alternative fuels, including hydrogen, and the deployment also of the associated infrastructure. So it’s therefore important for all of us to keep this in mind during future discussions. Together we should invest our way out of the crisis.

name: Salvatore De Meo
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow rapporteurs, Mr Mureşan and Mr Tang, for their excellent work on this initiative. As draftsman of the opinion of the AGRI Committee, I would like to confirm that the agricultural sector will be an active part in achieving the objectives of the Green Deal. Europe is a world leader in agriculture for quality, food safety, innovation and high environmental standards and Italy, I would like to remind you, is first in Europe in terms of the number of certified quality products. We certainly welcome the Commission's proposal to allocate EUR 7.5 billion to rural development under NextGenerationEU, but to address the critical issues of the COVID-19 emergency, companies need more direct payments and sectoral programmes. If we want modern and competitive agriculture, combining the objectives set out in the Green Deal with safeguarding production levels, we must not, however, reduce the amounts allocated to agriculture and rural development. In order to achieve the objectives of the Farm to Fork and Biodiversity strategies, we need new eu own resources. We cannot deprive farmers of part of the current CAP resources and then ask them to engage in a green transition.

name: Romeo Franz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In order to achieve a comprehensive and successful ecological transformation and modernisation of the economy and society, and thus to achieve the commission's priority of a Green New Deal, we need to promote synergies between the Green New Deal and EU programmes in the areas of education, volunteering and culture.  Erasmus+, the European Solidarity Corps and Creative Europe are important instruments against climate change. They are essential for the transition to a green economy and for a society based on sustainability, as they promote the necessary skills, such as raising awareness of environmental and climate change issues, especially among young people, who need to be disseminated for a new socio-economic environment. This environment requires creative, inclusive and technically innovative solutions to meet environmental challenges. There must therefore be greater cooperation in the EU between the areas of education, the environment and climate change.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. As the European Union, we have set ourselves an ambitious climate target, and this objective will only be achievable if we also trigger investment accordingly. I believe that this is undisputed.  The money for investment must also come from somewhere. I believe that this too is undisputed. And the report we are voting on today is therefore rightly called: 'How do we finance the Green Deal?' I therefore have a bit of trouble understanding why we are only dealing with the issue of public funding. It cannot be the case that only the state, only the European Union, should focus only on public pots and their equipment if we are to achieve a green deal.  We have experience from the Juncker Fund. In the Juncker Fund, in other words in the Fund for Strategic Investments, the great investment needs were not triggered by the use of public money, but by the fact that we were able to invest private money with public money. And that is what we should be focusing on: how can we really achieve this together? I say quite frankly that it has been very difficult to get these ideas in the report at all, even though most of the investment will end there. The difference is made by the private sector. It is businesses and households that can invest the lion's share. They need reliable, clear boundary conditions and planning certainty. That is what we should focus on and use the instruments to do so. Then we will achieve the Green Deal.

name: Pierre Larrouturou
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. Madam President, dear friends, two years ago Greta Thunberg began a school strike, a climate strike. Greta asked a simple question: what's the point of going to school if our leaders aren't interested in our future, if they're not interested in the climate emergency? Why learn science if scientists are not listened to by our leaders? Yes, it's time to listen to the scientists! This is the evolution of CO2 in the atmosphere over the past 1,000 years. I think that is clear. And the number of climate disasters has more than doubled in 30 years. What are we waiting for? Some people think that with the economic crisis, the evolution of CO2 is more favourable, but it is not. Wildfires in 2020 had never reached such a proportion: 440 deaths in forest fires in Australia, forest fires in Siberia, wildfires in California... Forest fires cause so much CO2 that 2020 is going to be one of the worst years for the evolution of CO2 in the atmosphere. On 29 October, the UN published an alarming report on biodiversity, which stated that unless we radically changed our way of life, pandemics like COVID—19 would multiply and cause more deaths. My friends, how can we avoid chaos? The report that we will vote on, thanks to Paul and Siegfried, reminds us that it takes 600 billion investments each year to insulate buildings, make public transport, develop renewable energies... 600 billion public and private. This report provides concrete solutions to find the $600 billion and calls on heads of state to put them in place without delay. But this week, the budget negotiations ended. Parliament won... two billion. That is fine, and we want to increase the climate from 20 to 30 per cent of the overall budget. If we can do that - by cutting our budget, alas - that would be $15 billion more. Fifteen billion is good, but it is not at all the 600 billion that we are looking for. Our report reminds us that we need to find ways to subsidize (if we want everyone to insulate their home, there must be subsidies) and that a small tax on speculation would bring in $57 billion each year. And the report proposes to move forward in the framework of enhanced cooperation so as not to block unanimity. So I think there is something obscene when the heads of state tell us that there is no climate money, no money for health, no money for jobs, when the financial markets have never been at such a high level. Can't we tax speculation a little bit? Just as Greta asked the question two years ago: "Why continue to go to school if the leaders don't listen to us?", you know that I started my third week of hunger strike yesterday. It is time to tell politicians to listen to us, and I would like to address Mrs Merkel. In a month's time, there's the climate summit. Merkel wants an ambitious deal at the Climate Council on 10-11 December, but many countries will block the deal if there is no ambitious funding. Mrs Merkel, there is an urgent need for climate and health to relaunch enhanced cooperation on the speculation tax. We can do it in a few weeks.

name: Fabienne Keller
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, the investment plan for a sustainable Europe is the cornerstone of the Green Pact for Europe, because it is the one that will finance the energy transition. With this green pact, we have set ambitious climate targets to become the first neutral continent by 2050. It is now a question of giving it the means to do so. That is why we are calling for a legally binding spending target of 30% for climate and 10% for biodiversity in the EU budget as soon as possible. It is also the issue of taxonomy and its respect.  The report also stresses the creation of new own resources, to enable us to achieve a higher level of climate finance. Thus, the carbon adjustment mechanism at the borders will also allow us to combat our carbon leakage, carbon leakage, and encourage our partners to reduce their own greenhouse gas emissions. The recovery plan will of course have a major role to play in achieving our objectives. For example, we are calling for a 37% climate target to be applied to Next Generation EU spending. In short, it is a cross-cutting approach that we propose, mobilizing public and private resources, and all sectors. By combining all our strengths, we could achieve this EUR 600 billion a year in climate investments and thus achieve our ambitions for a neutral, job-creating Europe, in line with the Paris Agreements. This report is the result of working in cooperation with several committees, all of which have a key role: the environment, of course, but also agriculture, transport, culture and education. It is the result of a strong and shared will in our European Parliament to lead Europe towards a modern, competitive, job-creating and sober economy, in line with the expectations of our fellow citizens.

name: Joachim Kuhs
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Before I say anything about the financing of the Green Deal, I would like to begin by expressing my gratitude for being able to find refuge here in Berlin on a cold November day in the Liaison Office (EPLO). After all, for all the sad development that Parliament is almost almost closed, this is a way of talking to you now. I regret that, but, as I said, the ePLO staff cannot do anything about it here, and they have shown me what there is here, that there is, that there is, and the work they are doing here is a good job, and I would like to stress that at this point. Then I would also like to congratulate the President of the Commission on the terms she uses when it comes to the so-called green deal. At first, the word "deal" was always rather negatively burdened for me. In my previous work at the Public Prosecutor's Office in Mannheim, we imprisoned the dealers. And now, behold, thirty years later, this word is suddenly a wonderful word to use – and it is still marked with the adjective "green", with hope, and so on. So you can really only congratulate you for making these terms a miracle, almost a miracle bag. Today, when you talk about the Green Deal and even say "New Green Deal," a new deal, you're also reminded of all the things about American history and all that. Really, so you can't really do it better. But what's behind it? We are talking about EUR 1 trillion that you want to finance, and at the beginning there was talk of EUR 3 trillion. These are all just airlocks that you build here. How is this supposed to work? We are even prepared to break contracts now, they want to introduce bonds, they are looking for various financing options that have not existed at all before. That is something i have to say: it is simply going too far.  And that is why we should not be talking about financing the Green Deal, but about the financial implications for citizens, for individuals. Electricity prices will continue to rise, and we already have the highest electricity prices in Germany today. The regulations will reduce entire industries and the loss of competitiveness compared to the other major players in the world will become ever greater. That cannot be the future! That is why we should not be so afraid of climate change. Climate change is a fact, not a question, and it has always existed. It was also always the warm times that were the heydays of history. But what do you want to do now? I prefer to trust in the word that says in Genesis that from now on seed and harvest, frost and heat, summer and winter, day and night. And I would rather trust these promises of God than the utopian promises of today's climate religion.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the debate about the investment plan on how to finance a Green Deal comes hand-in-hand, of course, with the situation of the pandemic that we are living through. We have been seeing the European institutions taking extraordinary measures, mobilising a lot of resources with the Recovery Fund. We have now an agreement with the MFF, and all of this is very important that it is completely aligned with the objectives of the Green Deal. There are some issues in the report that I would like to stress today that are particularly important for us. To speed up the own-resources debate, as we agreed on the MFF, but also to continue our fight against tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and also, Commissioner, the enforcement of our anti-money laundering legislation, which is of extreme importance. But we also need to make sure that the companies that are benefiting from public support in these difficult times commit to strictly respect the objectives of the Green Deal, and also we need to make sure that the big technological companies that are benefiting from the situation that we are living through pay also their fair share to our society. In that context, I think that the report is a very useful tool in those debates that we are having. I would like to thank Siegfried Mureşan and Paul Tang and the rest of the shadow rapporteurs for excellent work in common. We as Greens, together with other colleagues, have tabled additional amendments to the plenary to enrich the text, which I hope can have the support of our colleagues. One of them calls on the Commission to disclose the exposure of EU funds to the EU taxonomy objectives and categories, and the other one – very important – will call on the Member States to act against tax avoidance and also to put their public expenditure in line with the goals of the Green Deal. I hope we can have the support of the other Members to those proposals and I would like to thank again the co—rapporteurs for their excellent work.

name: Bogdan Rzońca
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I want to make it very clear that we will not pursue our dreams of climate neutrality without investment support from the countries that are most vulnerable to energy and those that are taking off from the furthest positions. Such countries in the European Union are. The European Union is not an area of economic equality in terms of energy, too.  Climate objectives should not be pursued at the expense of energy poverty and job losses. The European Parliament's overly ambitious climate policy will certainly destabilise fiscal policy, as it will force the poorer countries of the European Union to take out huge loans.  Clean ecological space is important, but it must not cause some countries to grow faster and others slower because they will not simply find their own resources for a modern system and modern industry. A clean energy system based on sun, wind, atom, hydrogen should of course play an important role, but it can be accompanied, for example, by gas. In this area, we are making a great revolution, and no revolutions in human history have worked, so if we give up some gas power very quickly, it will lead to another crisis.  I therefore ask everyone to be rational on this issue, because we already have a problem with the pandemic and with the economy, which is why I propose that the ECR Group vote against this report.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, in order to deal with the social emergency as well as to finance ecological bifurcation, we are always told the same story: it is too expensive, our States cannot afford it. So I'm going to try to answer this simple question: who can afford to pay?  Are you going to tell me that companies - which are profiting on the crisis, and are also responsible for the environmental disaster - do not have the means? Take, for example, Amazon, which is swimming in an ocean of happiness with a health crisis that has tripled its profits in a single quarter, not to mention its CEO, Jeff Bezos, whose fortune exceeds $180 billion. One might wonder, however, whether it could not be used. Are you going to tell me that speculators - who make their butter on yoyo variations in wild stock prices - cannot afford it? While we pay up to 20% VAT when we shop, the sharks of finance pay 0.0%. So our proposal is simple: tax crisis profiteers and financial transactions. You will no longer be able to tell us that we cannot afford to invest in renewable energy, clean transport, building renovation. But the agreement reached on Tuesday on the European budget refuses to take these common-sense measures: no mention of a tax on the profiteers of a consequential crisis, a hypothetical tax on financial transactions, reduced to a congruous portion and referred to the Greek calendars. You see, to the question "who has the means?", finally, it is quite easy to answer. But I ask myself another one. What are you going to tell your children? "Sorry, we preferred to sacrifice your future to satisfy lobbies and multinationals"?

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Dear Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, we have an obligation, the duty, to combat climate change, to protect, to defend biodiversity, to promote sustainable growth, to defend territorial, economic, social cohesion and inclusion. For all this and because we have a planet with limited resources, where we have to live well in it, it takes investment, but it is also necessary, and I draw attention, to remove administrative barriers. Where is the Energy Union? My country produces wind energy which is not fully used because then it cannot enter the European market - there are no interconnections.  Where is the Digital Union? Where is a Union where rail transport connects us all? It does not exist and does not exist because we have a problem, let us be serious in the Council, which is little more than the sum of the 27 national selfishness. We need investment, but we also need to remove these barriers, without which we will continue to be dependent, for example, on Russia's supply, when we could be energy independent. Look what the Council has done: it eliminated the Strategic Investments window from InvestEU, when we needed, more than ever, this window and these investments. And then the removal of "proudly alone" barriers was never a solution.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we started, just over a year ago, this legislature with a very remarkable climatic ambition. This Parliament demanded a clear commitment to the New Green Deal from the Commission at the investiture session of Ursula von der Leyen. But certainly some of us were wondering how we were going to be able to finance that ambition. We were aware that the Union has a high legislative, regulatory power in order to reform, market by market, the legal rules to steer the European economy towards the objective of complying with the Paris Agreements. The pandemic has had a tremendous impact, it is having an abysmal health and economic impact, but it has enabled vehicular, it has enabled the creation of a European investment instrument that is a necessary condition to meet the ambitions of the New Green Deal. This Next Generation EU instrument must help to resolve in the short term the recession we are suffering, but it must also contribute to this economic modernisation of the European Union and clearly orient it towards the objectives of the Paris Agreement. I believe that this report - I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs - is on the right track.

name: Gilles Boyer (Renew).
text: Madam President, with the Green Pact for Europe, the European Union has adopted a new growth strategy, with the aim of achieving climate neutrality by 2050 and we must now give ourselves the means to achieve this objective. Commissioner, this report is a signal of ambition and coherence on the part of the European Parliament. The fight against climate change will only be possible if new budgetary capacities are created, new resources are created, a favourable framework for mobilising sustainable private and public investment is our European taxonomy, and the european Central Bank and the European Central Bank are all about greening the level of monetary and investment policies. So, Commissioner, this investment plan is a first step and I am particularly pleased that taxonomy, which we have recently adopted, is at the heart of this report. It is a concrete tool that lays the groundwork for a common classification that allows investors to clearly know which activities are considered environmentally sustainable. And this tool must now be our frame of reference for all European, public and private investments. Our Renew Europe Group will play its full role in implementing these measures. I wanted to thank our rapporteurs, Paul Tang and Siegfried Mure-an, who have done an outstanding job under difficult conditions to adopt this ambitious report.

name: Roman Haider (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her To start with, this report is a mixture of wishful thinking and denial of reality. In doing so, however, he is also showing the dilemma of this Green Deal, which has been made a fetish by the EU. New and ever-wid targets are being set, but it is completely unclear how they will be achieved. It is also completely unclear how these objectives will be financed. Just to illustrate the scale of the scale: to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% alone – and this is the old target – there will be a minimum requirement of EUR 622 billion per year – per year! - adopted. That is EUR 6.2 trillion in total overspending over ten years. Is it at all clear to the authors of this report that we are in an economic crisis, the effects of which we cannot even estimate now? We are in the worst economic crisis since the Second World War. The Green Deal will further weaken our economy, even destroy the industry in some areas – and 6.2 trillion euros are to be shaken off our sleeves! On the other hand, squaring the circle is almost a breeze. I wonder: in these fantasies, do you really know what is happening in the rest of the world? Have you ever looked a little outside the box? Africa is just beginning to industrialize, and countless new coal-fired power plants are under construction or in the pipeline. Nuclear power plants are experiencing a renaissance in India and China, and at the same time, with your plans in Europe, you are destroying the most environmentally friendly industry in the world, an industry whose innovation and investment power we would desperately need in the coming decades. That is why these proposals are completely ill-conceived wishful thinking. Wishful thinking that is dangerous for Europe's economy and Europe's citizens.

name: Rasmus Andresen (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In order to stop the climate crisis, we need to change the rules of the economic game. We all know that our current financial and economic system is increasing resource consumption and exacerbating the climate crisis. That is why we must not measure public budgets solely by debt. There is no debt on a dead planet.  In the future, public budgets will only be good if they are compatible with the Paris climate agreement. That is why it is right that we will enshrine clear climate targets and a binding biodiversity quota in the EU budget. This can also be a model for national public budgets.  We must stop climate-damaging investments. Airports, motorways, large-scale fossil-fuel infrastructure projects or even climate-damaging agriculture – everything needs to be put to the test. And what applies to public investment must also be applied to private ones. Already, large insurers and financial funds are disanotous from fossil fuel mining. That is a good thing, but now we also need a binding framework for this, which will also make it easier for companies to act. We need to get out of the promotion of fossil energy. We cannot afford to continue to promote fossil fuels such as coal or gas for future generations.  I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Siegfried Mure'an and Mr Paul Tang, for the report. Let us now work together to ensure that our financial system is going from problem to problem to solution!

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Above all, the Investment Plan for a sustainable Europe must support the countries and regions with the most difficult starting points and the greatest transformational challenges. It should therefore take into account their level of wealth as measured by gdp per capita, as well as the energy poverty rate.  In such a difficult situation is my country, Poland, whose investment needs for the current reduction target are estimated at EUR 240 billion by 2030 only and are twice as high as the EU average. In this situation, the reduction in funding for the Just Transition Fund, which was intended to support green investment, from the €40 billion projected by the Commission to just €17.5 billion in the budget, is of the utmost concern.  If we want to achieve the objectives of the Green Deal, we must, on the one hand, respect the choice of the path of transformation made by individual countries and, on the other hand, allow all available technologies for the production of energy from sources such as atom, sun, wind, hydrogen and natural gas, which is, after all, a bridging fuel in the process of moving away from coal in the energy sector. Only this approach gives the chance that the implementation of the Green Deal will stand the test of time and will not put Member States on the path of different speeds of economic and social development.

name: Jessica Polfjärd (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The European economy needs to change. With the right policy, we can enable and finance the green transition. But we do not have, either in public or in private, endless resources. How we spend the money most efficiently will therefore be a crucial issue. Similarly, it is important that we get the whole of the Union, both citizens and businesses. The public has an important role to play in this, both in terms of general rules of the game but also in terms of funding. We have a responsibility to use our taxpayers' money smartly and efficiently. We know, however, that the public will not be able to do this on its own. Many people seem to think that restrictions on private business are what will cope with the green transition. Nothing could be further from the truth. The private sector can and does want to contribute to a greener economy, and they are already doing so in several sectors. Properly designed, with a green investment plan, we can achieve an economy that lowers emissions but also contributes to jobs and competitiveness. Helping and supporting rather than suspecting and obstructing must be the European way. That's just how we set out a path globally that others are also prepared to follow and be inspired by.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, climate emergencies, but now also those of the health crisis, have made it even more clear that we must govern, invest, produce and consume in radically different ways. But this post-world will not become a reality without a major impulse on our part. The European Sustainable Investment Plan must be a crucial part of this transformation. Indeed, if we do not invest in the right sectors and according to clear criteria that serve the objective of transforming to societies capable of responding to these crises, this post-world, however much necessary, will be a wishful thinking. In several recent reports, the European Court of Auditors has pinned the Commission by making serious criticisms, on the one hand, of the way European funds are spent and, on the other hand, on the fact that the indicators for monitoring our expenditure are not adequate. This means that the funds would not be used wisely, but also that the evaluation methods we use are not even able to tell us precisely whether the funds used are having the desired effect. In this context, I thank the work of the two co-ministers, who integrate all this data. It seems essential to us that investments in the sustainable investment plan, both private and public, respect the do no harm principle and that a significant part of the various financial instruments be dedicated to climate and the environment, in accordance with the criteria of green taxonomy. With regard to expenditure monitoring, the report therefore rightly stresses the need to adopt new instruments to ensure that European spending is moving in the right direction. I will conclude by praising Pierre Larrouturou's work on the question of how to finance this fund. The financial transaction tax will allow us to move faster and stronger towards the objective.

name: Martin Hojsík (Renew).
text: – Madam President, two days ago, we achieved something very important for our future, the deal about the MFF, as well as the Next Generation Fund, is not only about ensuring 30% for climate, but also about 10% for biodiversity by 2026. I’m glad that our colleagues in the Council finally understood that we don’t only face a climate crisis, we also face a biodiversity crisis. But our success to become sustainable, our success to achieve carbon neutrality, live within planetary boundaries, can only be done then when its not about 30 or 10%, when its about policy coherence. When the entire budget, the remaining 70%, in terms of climate for example, are not undermining the effort. Our integration of sustainability in our policies and politics has to also cover public funds. Today we discuss the plan to unlock EUR 1 trillion of sustainable investments over ten years. We cannot afford and we don’t want pretty packaging for an empty box, no empty promises and no greenwashing. We already lost many years and cannot lose more.  That is why I believe that all EU-supported investments and finance need to be subject to the EU taxonomy, and need to be in line with the ‘do no harm’ principle. We cannot undermine what we will achieve. We need to make sure that not only our left hand knows what our right hand is doing, but that we work hand-in-hand.

name: Henrike Hahn (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Green Deal is an ambitious economic recovery plan for a socio-ecological turnaround in Europe – for climate, for the environment and for people. The Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe, including the Mechanism for a Fair Transition, aims to bring sustainable social economy together with the Paris climate goals. And I find it always astonishing, even as rapporteur on two pillars of the mechanism for a fair transition in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, to see again and again how much resistance is torpedoed or delayed down to the smallest details of this clever Green Deal concept in Parliament, in the Council and also in the Commission. The EU Taxonomy Regulation contains clear guidelines on what is sustainable, and we have a good instrument that can be developed. And there is no need to look around each other in the application, to give just one example. If the EU Member States reconcile their economy and public spending with the Green Deal, that is a great opportunity, and this push must come from the EU. The Green Deal is our great opportunity in Europe.

name: Anna Zalewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In order to implement the green deal, in order to invest green, it is important to remember that this must be done for citizens and citizens, that it must be done in a fair, solidarity, flexible and at the same time real way. Unfortunately, solidarity, flexibility and justice have already been ruined by climate law. There is no European solidarity, energy solidarity or solidarity in the pursuit of zero carbon at European Union level.  We have forgotten about the citizens. In the impact assessment, we have information that millions of jobs will be lost and 25% of citizens will live in energy poverty. We are not showing how we will address this. At the same time, we see in the report that we have a huge investment gap, that we simply do not have the money to do so. The European Commission's communication, which counts how much money it needs to meet the 40% target, let alone 60%, amounts to €662 billion a year.  On the other hand, the Commission is cutting funding for the Just Transition Fund and is also willing to appropriate the ECJ, and we are yet to see a review of the ECJ. This system needs to be strengthened, it needs to be given more opportunities in the modernisation fund and, above all, to think about creating a new energy justice fund, because it will be fair, solidarity-based, real and closer to the citizens.

name: Isabel Benjumea Benjumea (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to take advantage of this speech to say that I do not share President Sassoli's decision to have closed the European Parliament to a minimum and to have limited to a minimum the activity of this very important institution. Precisely at a time when Europe is experiencing a terrible health, social and economic crisis, it needs its institutions to be working at the same time. Today we came to talk about the Green Deal, how to finance the Green Deal. It is certainly the great European bet, it is the Commission's great project and, of course, it is supported by the European Parliament. But I would ask you not to lose perspective on what is happening right now in Europe, not to lose the prospect that there are thousands of entrepreneurs having to close their businesses, thousands of European citizens losing their jobs; that the queues of hunger are getting longer in Europe. Therefore, the Green Deal has to serve the first and highest priority, which is to create jobs.  The Green Deal cannot be a project to satisfy the ideologies of certain political parties. We must create a competitive Europe, a Europe that bets on innovation, a Europe that bets on the private sector; we must bet on a Europe that works to provide solutions to real problems.  The Green Deal has to be a reality, as long as it serves to create jobs, to make us more competitive and to make us stronger. And if we have that in our heads, it will be a good thing for Europe, and if not, citizens will soon hold us accountable.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I should like to begin by thanking Paul and Siegfried for this report which gave us the opportunity to have this debate here in plenary. We all know: there is no trade-off between sustainable recovery and economic progress. We need to transform the economy. Mitigate the effects of climate change. The cost of inaction will certainly be much higher for Europe and the world. We need sustainable investment... But to do that, we have to give conditions to the public and private sector.  The pandemic is having a brutal impact on public finances. Gross Domestic Product had historic falls. Deficits of more than 10% and in Member States far from below 3% in the short term. Public debt almost reaching 200 %.   The Union must reform the budgetary rules. The rule of public debt. Seek solutions to encourage sustainable investment.  The effects of the pandemic on public debts is not a problem of a country or Europe. It is being - hardly be different - a global problem. That is why I am today challenging all leaders: a wide-ranging debate in the relevant international institutions and with the appropriate actors on how to deal with high levels of public debt and how to create conditions to promote sustainable investment. And I invite the European Commission to launch this initiative.

name: Ondřej Kovařík (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Executive Vice-President, in order to truly deliver on the ambitious objectives of the European Green Deal, it must be sustainable not only environmentally, but also socioeconomically. To achieve this goal, we need to mobilise an unprecedented level of investment. In terms of public funds, we will have many instruments in our toolbox under the umbrella of the next MFF and recovery plan. But public funds will not, simply, be enough. Rough estimates of the level of investments required clearly show this. Without attracting private investors, we will miss the target. The EU and Member States must work together to tap into synergies between public and private finance. We have to create favourable business environments, adequate regulatory frameworks, relevant and accessible financial instruments, and above all, incentives for companies to invest in sustainable technologies. Our business sector will be a key enabler to climate-related policies. SMEs will be front—line actors in this regard. Therefore, we need to assist their efforts through appropriate policy action. Finally, it is also essential that sufficient funding is available for the regions and people who will be most acutely affected by the transition to more sustainable economic activities.

name: Elżbieta Kruk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe is one of the fundamental elements of the European Green Deal. However, the document submitted to us cannot be supported. Above all, there is no sufficiently ambitious financial plan without which the implementation of the transition can lead to irreswerable socio-economic damage. There is no long-term support for the countries and regions facing the most difficult challenges, so as not to put the Union on a path of different speeds. There is no guarantee of flexibility in choosing the path of transformation, and finally there is no reflection on the fact that pre-prepared solutions have not taken into account the economic crisis that we are facing. The energy transition is a huge financial burden. In times of crisis, will the necessary economic resources be available in the Union? There are increasing voices from experts to slow down the transition, as the priority must now be to emerge from the crisis caused by the strategy adopted by the states in relation to the coronavirus, in particular the lockdown of the economy. Anti-crisis measures must therefore be chosen in such a way as to protect the climate and the environment without further harm to the economy. Consideration should be given to suspending the CO2 emissions trading system and the work on the European Green Deal in general during the crisis. Let us slow down the pace of the EU's ideological climate policy so as not to lead to a catastrophe that future generations will pay for. It's time for a Green Deal lockdown.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Green Deal, NextGenerationEU, the long-term budget, the proposed investment plan belong together. That is a package. It is not just an investment and a financing package, it is also a package for the future, and for us NextGenerationEU is the opening of a great window into the future.  And Ursula von der Leyen has made it very clear: if you mobilize so much money, you need so much investment, you take up so much new money, then the package must have one goal – to leave the young generation, the children and their grandchildren a better, a greener, a more digital, a more democratic, a more social European Union and, hopefully, a world.  And that's what it's all about: earmarking, and we're investing in it, and the Green Deal is at the heart of NextGenerationEU. And this is not a spending of money, it is an investment, and the investment is intended to create further investments. That is our aim. That is the step-by-step plan and we need to see that as a whole. It is a program for an ever closer union. It is a programme for the European Union's exercise of responsibility for the future.

name: Aurore Lalucq (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is the world's second largest economy and yet it is still not equipped accordingly. It is a kind of League 1 club that is equipped as an amateur club, a beautiful amateur club but an amateur club anyway. Still no real budget, still no taxation, so that with every problem we have to rely on the European Central Bank, and so that with every ambitious project, we risk legitimately disappointing the Europeans. The fault of Europe? Rather the fault of the states that refuse to equip it properly and to give it the means. The strength of the report that is being proposed today on the financing of the Green Pact for Europe is, precisely, to finally give Europe the means to implement its environmental ambitions. This is a first step, although still imperfect, but it is an essential first step. So we parliamentarians have done our job. States, now, to pursue theirs and give us the means to meet environmental ambitions.

name: Jessica Stegrud (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I have taken note of the report on the investment plan for a sustainable Europe and the financing of the green deal. According to the investment base, the cost of climate action amounts to at least SEK 6,700 billion per year until 2030. Despite a record budget increase, there is no approximately SEK 5,000 billion per year. I have also put the question to the European Commission about the impact these objectives and measures will have on the global average temperature. It is noted that it will not be of decisive importance, but that further measures and even more money will be required. We are in the midst of a financial crisis that we have not yet seen the culmination or the end of. Moreover, for the first time in history, the Union is now to blame future generations in debt to save economically mismanaged countries during the pandemic. I wonder, who's going to pay for this? Are there states on the brink of bankruptcy? Are they the countries that are already funding the rest of the Union or are the future generations? This is not a serious plan to achieve any goals. This is a textbook example of how to undermine trust in politicians and the EU as a legitimate Union.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If you go out straight away, you will see that Parliament is well filled with permanent staff, with service personnel. The President does not want to see us here in Parliament. I think this is a scandal and it must have consequences. On the Green Deal, the Green Deal must be funded, clearly, in such a way that it has the greatest added value for the environment, and so that we take people with us and combine climate protection with jobs. The report really provides a great basis for this, and I therefore have only one message: let us not approach it too complicatedly and too ideologically. We already have a investment backlog of EUR 200 billion in the current budgetary framework. In other words, we have money in the Structural Funds that the Member States cannot spend because it is too complicated. And when the N+ rules expire now, the money will be spent on something, but not on European added value, and that must not happen to us when we finance the Green Deal. Let us therefore combine only a few, but all the more binding, conditions with the reconstruction plan: the energy transition, the corresponding infrastructure, must be a requirement, but not technology bans, the confusion of taxonomy. The Paris objectives are our yardstick, but not with the world-enhancing proposals of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The European Free Thinking, which are unfortunately again ideologically guided. This leads to funding chaos and frustration among SMEs. Paris is much easier and faster with emissions trading, innovation, a market economy, with an investment focus on environmental protection in the construction plan. And that's it.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The clock is ticking. In 7 years and 47 days, the rise in global temperature will exceed the tipping point. The books we learned from a few years ago in geography school are completely out of date today. Unfortunately, man led to such a disaster. Therefore, the European Green Deal should not only be the foundation of the programme, but also a real action that we must implement immediately.  Unfortunately, there are serious gaps in this foundation. According to the European Commission, at least €662 billion is needed each year to meet the 2030 climate targets. Poland itself needs between EUR 700 billion and EUR 900 billion if it wants to meet certain conditions. That is why we need to have a serious debate today on measures that will finance this most important challenge for humanity.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – (start of off-microphone intervention) ... China has paralyzed economies around the world, except its own, of course. And the tragedy that is thrown at us has biblical dimensions, and here we are pounding with green pacts, ecological transitions, mythical climatic emergencies and a whole series of apocalyptic prophecies about the end of the world. They don't realize that everything has changed with this pandemic. They continue to pretend that it is a priority to change the world, to make an ideological construction. This immense exercise, this colossal social engineering that they want to do with the Green Deal was absurd before and what it did was to detract from competitiveness to Europe without fixing any of the problems of the environment, but it is that, moreover, what we see now is that the economy is sinking throughout Europe – and in Spain in particular we are seeing it . There are the streets full of signs of trade closures, people are looking for food in the containers, there are some hunger queues that are growing in Spain every day, and we are still there with this social engineering, looking for formulas that have their origin in what is the permanent ideological pressure, to which a majority folds. Please, let's hope, let's have some common sense, let's go to the urgent, which is the social and economic emergency we have now, let's focus on people's lives and not on ideological, climatic and eco-economic landscapes.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, we live in dramatic times throughout Europe. People "leave", while medical and nursing staff exceed their powers. These hours, citizens are looking here, in Brussels, to see from us the road map that will lead not only to healing the wounds of this pandemic but also to the next day in the world. The Green Agreement is much more than a road map of economic transformation for a climate-neutral Europe. It's Europe's bet on the world map.  We are putting EUR 1.8 trillion of public money on the table and asking individuals to invest. For this reason, a stable environment is needed based on the criteria of taxonomics and, at the same time, an absolute pragmatic sense of a smooth transition that allows for stable investment and accessible energy. It also needs speed to ensure that own resources are immediately secured and voted on by the Member States and national parliaments. We need to move immediately to the transition from coal, and indeed through the Fair Transition Mechanism with the support provided for in the report, which involves resources from InvestEU, from the public sector loan facility and from the private sector. We need to strengthen tourism in Member States such as Greece, which was submerged after the pandemic. You know, the Green Deal isn't the plan that's going to solve everything. But it is the plan that will judge Europe's performance and its success can give Europe the global leadership for a sustainable future that we all want.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all thank you for this insightful and productive debate. Let me express my appreciation of the European Parliament’s aspiration and overall support for the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan. It is encouraging that the Parliament and the Commission are aligned in the stars to guide EU to the path of climate neutrality. We are, of course, deeply aware of the stark effects of the pandemic, but as we discussed, the significant challenges of climate change will not disappear with this. So the Sustainable Europe Investment Plan can steer the green transition in a way that supports and complements the recovery from the current health and economic crisis. The Sustainable European Investment Plan is well placed to encourage sustainable investments and help raise private finance to them. The Commission will do its utmost to make it a success. Most of the issues in your report reflects the Commission’s thinking, so there is a way forward and I look forward to continuing to work together in achieving our aligned objectives.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today and the final vote tomorrow, Friday 13 November. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen Avram (S&D)
