text: in writing. – Reaching our ambitious Paris Agreement goals is an objective shared by the majority in the EP. To make the EU Green Deal a success, we must acknowledge that not every Member State starts from the same point or has the same resources to face the transition challenges. As the Commission stated repeatedly and it is important to remind our citizens across the EU: the pledge to leave no one behind is central to the European Green Deal. The Just Transition Mechanism and Fund seek to address the transition in vulnerable coal and carbon-intensive regions. The Recovery and Resilience Facility financed from the EUR 750 billion Next Generation EU will allow Member States to boost investments that are essential for a sustainable recovery in a fair manner. The Modernisation Fund will provide over the next 10 years ample support to the ten lower-income Member States, helping them modernise their energy systems and improve energy efficiency. This resolution states that ‘the principle of a just transition should be mainstreamed throughout the Green Deal, and the JTF should in particular focus on the regions most heavily dependent on fossil fuels’. Keeping this in mind, I am sure each Member States will do its utmost to reach the transition goals.

name: Gunnar Beck (ID)
text: Writing. – In January, the Commission proposed its plan to finance the Green Deal to achieve a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and climate neutrality by 2050. For something as complex as climate change, it would cost the comfortable round figure of 1 trillion euros. That is a thousand billion. How fitting! To this end, half of the multiannual European budget, or more than 500 billion, should be used for environmentally friendly investments. Or at least to shady marketers who can sell their projects in Brussels as green. To finance this madness, the EU needs its own budgetary capacity. What is now banned under the EU Treaties. Parliament is proposing six new taxes levied by the EU and directly attributed to the EU. Of course, much has changed since January. According to the Commission's forecast, GDP will have fallen by 7.4% in 2020. In the euro area, almost 8%. Well below the global economic slowdown of 4.3%. People are already suffering from the lockdown. The social liabilities resulting from this health crisis, the enormous costs of financing immigration, and the massive creation of money that leads to higher asset prices are already making it difficult enough for Europeans. Let us not put any further burden straining on the citizens.

name: Marek Belka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are talking today about the financing of the European Green Deal, which is of paramount importance to our citizens. Although member states will bear the most expenditure, green costs are not money thrown away: it is investment for future generations, for our children and grandchildren.  It is crucial that green deal funding is hand-in-hand with the recovery of the European economy after the ongoing pandemic. That is why we have been working on the European Union's own resources since the beginning of our term of office. If we want to approach the social, economic and environmental challenges of climate change in an ambitious way, we should ensure that green investments are not financed solely by so-called green charges, such as the aviation fuel tax or the carbon tax on imports of products.  That is why I would like to call on the Member States not to unilaterally introduce taxes for digital giants. We all need to be patient and wait for the results of the OECD's work and the Commission's proposals. Only joint action on this issue can ensure effectiveness, and revenues from digital tax must go to the common Budget of the Union, not the national coffers. Indeed, all these challenges of transformation are also common, and only together can we face them. For my country – Polish – it is an ambitious, generational step, but to quote the bard of Wojciech Młynarski's Polish song, "we still play green"!

name: Marc Botenga (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Either it will be the workers and the people to pay for this Green Deal, or the millionaires and the big multinationals. And I warn you, if you are going to use the Revision of the Energy Taxation Directive, scheduled for 2021, to raise the price that people pay for their energy, you will face a yellow jackets bis movement and not just in France. The idea of a Financial Transaction Tax, on the other hand, is important. I support her. Let's tax the financial markets. But this tax alone will not be enough to ensure a just climate transition. In order for workers not to pay for this green pact, we need a real capital tax, such as the millionaire tax we propose as an authentic left. Nor is a social transition conceivable without ending the tax havens, which you tolerate within and outside the European Union! And what are you waiting for to guarantee an effective minimum rate of 25% for the taxation of European multinationals? You see... There is really no reason to charge workers. Alternatives exist. They're here. Act!

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Achieving climate neutrality by the European Union is a very ambitious plan, especially in the current situation in the fight against the Covid-19 pandemic. However, such a plan will not be achieved without the development of a sufficiently ambitious investment plan and financial support that would allow Member States to transform. This plan must support, in particular, the countries and regions with the most difficult starting points and the greatest transformational challenges. We are aware of the very different european countries, including in the field of technological advancement and the efficiency of the spheres we are discussing here. It is therefore worrying that the Fair Transition Fund will be significantly reduced from EUR 17.5 billion compared to the COMMISSION's proposal of EUR 40 billion in May 2020. This direction of budgetary change raises serious doubts as to whether the estimated appropriations from this envelope are proportionate to the ambition of the Green Deal programme. Therefore, if the objectives of the programme do not change as well as measures to help them achieve them, the more important is the importance of flexibility in choosing a path of transformation that would enable Member States to achieve common objectives, taking into account the protection of those citizens and economic sectors most affected by the pandemic. There is a need to significantly increase funding for the Modernisation Fund or to create a separate fund for less prosperous Member States, based, for example, on the energy poverty rate.

name: Krzysztof Jurgiel (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Investment Plan for a sustainable Europe is an investment pillar of the Green Deal. The plan aims to mobilise at least EUR 1 trillion in investment for sustainable development over the next decade. A positive aspect of this plan is to pay attention to digitalisation, research and development, strategic autonomy, strengthening the internal market and calling for the creation of a competitive industrial sector. However, there are many elements that negatively affect my perception of this report. Ambitious reforms offer an opportunity to boost the development of the economy. We must take advantage of it, but we must also reduce risks such as increased energy poverty and job losses. I would like to stress the importance of maintaining the possibility of supporting technologies using natural gas as a transitional fuel, as it is crucial for Member States that are still dependent on coal. I assess the principle of non-material damage to the environment, including m.in. exclusion of support for natural gas, which is to be applied in the RRF instrument, negatively. It is also shocking to reduce the FST from EUR 40 billion to EUR 17.5 billion. The EU's achievement of climate neutrality will not succeed without a sufficiently ambitious investment plan and financial support that would allow each Member State to transform. This plan must primarily support countries and regions with the most difficult starting points and major transformational challenges.

name: Benoît Lutgen (PPE)
text: In writing. Environmental and budgetary issues largely dominate the agenda of our plenary session. And we need votes that live up to these issues. That is why, in the vote of the report on the "Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe - the financing of the European Green Pact/Green Deal", launched by the President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, I will support the following provisions which, in my view, have become imperatives: first, that investments under the European Recovery Plan respect the principle of 'first, don't harm' (to ensure that the EU meets its commitments under the Paris Agreement) and, secondly, that the EU's multi-year financial framework/budget does not provide support or funds for activities that could undermine climate and environmental targets. I am also in the hope of the Commission assessing and identifying activities that significantly undermine environmental sustainability.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Ecological Pact is one of the main political priorities for the European Union. As a member of the European Parliament, I underline the fundamental role of this institution, the only one directly elected by citizens at European level, in the fight against climate change and the transition to a sustainable economy. This report reflects this commitment and aims to ensure coherence between Discourse and European actions. The Recovery and Resilience Mechanism is required to follow the ambition expressed in the European Climate Law, contributing in accordance with the "no significant harm" principle. In this sense, it should be stressed the importance of increasing the capacity of public bodies to intervene, in particular by establishing new own resources, including green taxes, but also with the fight against tax avoidance, which restricts national budgets so much. At the same time, in order to achieve our objectives, we recognize the need to mobilize more private investment aligned with sustainability criteria. Given the demands of the Covid-19 crisis, but also the variable impact of the climate transition, a balance between the ecological and social dimensions must be ensured. We must create jobs and opportunities for all citizens.

name: Dan-Ştefan Motreanu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe will form the basis of the European Ecological Pact and the transition to a more sustainable and resilient economy. Under this plan, the European Union must mobilise €1,000 billion in public and private investment by 2030. In view of the negative economic prospects generated by the crisis caused by the CoVID-19 pandemic, I stress that the Union's success in achieving the objective of climate neutrality will depend on the adequacy of funding for Member States, taking into account different starting points. It is extremely important to ensure the necessary funding for the most vulnerable regions in the EU, both through the Fair Transition Fund (JTF), whose budget has been greatly reduced, and through the two additional pillars of the Fair Transition Mechanism. I welcome the fact that the Modernisation Fund is designed to support investments to improve energy efficiency in the ten lower-income Member States, as well as the efforts of the European Investment Bank (EIB) to devote 50% of its climate action operations. In this way, I call on the European Investment Bank to pay particular attention to the sectors and regions that are most affected by the transition.

name: Alexandr Vondra (ECR)
text: Writing. – Despite some partial positive points, we are once again dealing with a reality-non-respecting plan in which enthusiasm for a green future suppresses all issues that pop up on every intellectually honest person, especially in relation to some points. The main part of the plan dates back to before the coronavirus outbreak, which significantly damaged European economies. On the contrary, I believe that, in this situation, member states and the private sector need to untie their hands so that they can use the common means according to their current needs, not to impose new conditions in line with the EU's long-term environmental and climate ambitions, and even to revise the existing rules in order to finance the Green Deal, for which, moreover, not all parameters, let alone impact studies, are yet known. The EU's new own resources remain a euphemism for new taxes, while all the complications of the plan are to make up for the phrases that they are the world's "trendsetters" in green policy.
